PUBLIC ARCHIVES ARCHIVES PUBLIQUES CANADA
Ottawa,
April 6, 1944.

EX'D.

Mr. F.J.C. Ball, Indian Agent, 416 Federal Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 5th instant, I regret that in some manner your voucher No. 301 was mislaid and the account was not paid. However, arrangements are being made to have cheque issued immediately and sent to Muir's Hardware, Westview, British Columbia.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Ottawa.

I beg to advise that I am informed by Muir's Hardware, of Westview, B.C., that they have not yet received payment for the heater supplied for Sliammon Indian Day School last November. This was covered by our Voucher No.301, for $40.10, dated November 23, 1943. It would be appreciated if you would kindly let me know whether a cheque was issued. This stove was purchased on the instructions of the Indian Commissioner.

Indian Agent.

B/DH.

I enclose a copy of a letter of the 30th instant which was inadvertently sent directly to Ottawa instead of to you, concerning much needed repairs to the Day School at Sliammon I.R. No. 1.

Since writing, I have received additional information from Mr. and Mrs. Gallagher, the school teacher and field matron respectively. They report that pupils are endangered by falling plaster, one large piece narrowly missing a small girl's head recently. After rain the school floor is a mass of puddles and the stove heat makes a steam which dampens the class room. It is usually noon before the floor dries out.

I note that reports of November 12th 1944 and June 6th 1945 by the Provincial Inspector of Schools refer to the school toilets as dirty and needing repairs. They frequently blow down, the roofs leak and the sides are split.

There is at present cardboard in some of the broken windows and it would seem that we are setting the Indians a very poor example in permitting children to attend school under such conditions.

The dispensary roof also leaks badly and only one chair is available for Indian patients; this is usually wet from roof leaks. The water supply is non-existent during summer months, so there is no fire protection, neither has the matron any hot or cold running water for treatment of patients. The water situation will form the subject of another report.

In urging acceptance of the only tender submitted vide my letter referred to above, I would submit that we are inviting severe criticism over the conditions of this School. Will you kindly air mail this to Ottawa with the necessary recommendations?

(H.E. Taylor)
Indian Agent

Referring to your letter of the 28th ultimo enclosing copy of District School Inspector Davey's report on the Sliammon Indian Day School, and to that portion of your letter regarding construction of new school toilets.

The need for toilets and other repairs was the subject of correspondence with you last Fall, but funds available only permitted the re-shingling of the school and dispensary roof. Following receipt of your letter I asked the school teacher, Mr. Gallagher, to obtain an estimate for new toilets. As a result I have a price from one John Gibson, building contractor of Wildwood Heights near Powell River.

I enclose a copy of his tender and you will note that it includes other repair work.

The additional work is certainly necessary, and in view of the difficulty of obtaining tenders for these small repair jobs, I would recommend that the other work be done at the same time. The locks on the school doors are broken and the doors are continually banging. The woodshed is unsightly and new steps are needed.

(H. E. Taylor),

Reference attached voucher No. 95 in favour of Humphrey Plumbing, Westview, B.C. I would advise as follows:

Since the teacher, Mr. Trembley, resigned last Fall because of ill health, the teacherage has been vacant.

Mr. Trembley omitted to turn off the water and the Indians did not concern themselves. Consequently, during the severely cold weather prevailing in December, the plumbing was frozen up.

I visited the Reserve last week and made arrangements for the arrival of another teacher, Miss O'Connor.

It was necessary to engage a plumber to inspect the water pipes and thaw out the kitchen and bathroom plumbing and tighten and adjust all connections.

He also replaced a window in the dispensary, broken by an unknown party.

I also arranged for fires to be maintained in the house and for house cleaning pending the arrival of Miss O'Connor who will go to Shapton on the 21st instant.

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Superintendent.

A recent inspection of the Departmentally owned teacherage in Sliammon I.R. No. 1 revealed a pressing need for the repapering and repainting of all rooms.

Difficulty in obtaining and retaining teachers in such reserves is enhanced when the accommodation provided is gloomy and repellent for lack of paint and paper.

There are three bedrooms in the house, a bathroom, kitchen, pantry, dispensary and dining and living rooms.

Further deterioration will result in heavier expense later for maintenance.

The accompanying tender from Gulf Coast Construction Company in Westview, B.C. is $405.35 for work as specified.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter of April 6, we have made an inspection of the work as outlined in your letter to the Sliammon School and wish to make a suggestion regarding the plaster. The plaster on the ceiling is beyond repair, apparently due to a leaky roof at sometime has caused it to crack all over and is liable to all come down should it be touched. We would like to suggest covering all the plaster with a ¼" P.V. Hardboard, this will make a more substantial job. We have estimated the cost of the labor and material to do the walls and ceiling of the classroom, cloakroom and store-room to be $256.50.

Painting the interior walls and ceiling of the classroom, cloakroom and store-room with two coats 1st. quality paint for the sum of $186.50.

Repairs to sink outlet all for the sum of $15.00 includes new trap and pipe.

Supply material and hardware for two doors to outside toilets all for the sum of $14.00.

We have received a memorandum from our Minister's office concerning contracts and reading as follows:

"On the 5th of this month a letter was received from the Secretary of the Cabinet stating "in future, and as a matter of normal Government policy, contracts for public works would be awarded only after tenders had been called for on a firm bid basis". While technically it might be claimed that after one tender had been received the conditions laid down by the Cabinet had been met, I imagine that that was not what was intended. It may not always be practicable to secure more than one bid, but it is thought that in future when a recommendation is being made to the Deputy Minister that a contract be let, it be stated whether public tenders are invited, and if not, what the circumstances are that justify the acceptance of an individual tender."

This means that it would not be possible to secure an Order-in-Council for the acceptance of the tender from the Precision Housing Company Ltd., until we have assured the Minister that we have attempted to secure other prices.

In the case of Cape Mudge we had already advertised for tenders and so it was relatively easy to obtain the authority. We also had a tender from Prefabricated Structures Ltd.

Sir:

I beg to acknowledge receipt of your letter of the 19th ultimo, authorizing the repairs and renovating at the teacher's residence on Sliammon Indian Reserve.

I have not seen the work done as I have not had occasion to visit the Sliammon Reserve, but have received word from the Field Matron that it is most satisfactory, and considerable more work was done than expected for the amount of $150.00 allowed. The outside of the building was given three coats of paint, and the roof shingled and new steps both back and front were constructed, three leaks fixed on the roof, and windows puttied. Bath-room, kitchen and scullery were renovated or salsomined, and the dispensary, which is part of the residence, was given one coat of paint. Other rooms were papered, but this work was done voluntarily by the occupants and is not charged. I enclose herewith the Return of Labour.

Mr. Wood's reports that he found the Indians very slow and not anxious to assist. All work done by this man previously has been first-class work, and judging from reports received on this job it is more than satisfactory. I respectfully recommend payment of the labour accounts enclosed herewith, and hope to inspect the work as soon as I can visit Sliammon. I do not wish to make a special trip on account of the expense.

Accounts for material have not been received as yet, but will be forwarded as soon as possible.

B/GM.

I have the honour to be,

Sir,
Your obedient servant,

Sir:

Warren, of the Dominion Water Branch, visited the Reserve with regard to the water supply but did not make a written report. Extract from Inspector Barry's report on the Sliammon Indian day school dated March 24, 1939:

Though I have not mentioned it in the actual report on the school I believe that Mr. McGuinness could teach the boys some worthwhile manual work if he were supplied with a few simple tools and the ordinary rough lumber. I should like to recommend that simple tools to the value of some $20.00 be supplied to the Sliammon Indian Day School and that at the same time lumber of various assorted sizes to a value of not more than $10.00 be made available. The teacher tells me that he is able to instruct in simple manual training and the boys could make a few simple articles of use in the school, a small bench, table etc. If you agree with me that such equipment and lumber might be supplied I would ask that this simple set of tools be supplied in time for the opening of school in September of this year.

The girls are learning to knit now and I shall have some suggestions to make with regard to their vocational training at a later date.

(Sgd.) Gerald H. Barry.

July 12, 1943.

F.J.C. Ball, Esq., Indian Agent, Vancouver, B.C.

Replying to your letter of the 20th ultimo regarding Sliammon Indian Day School, I would request that you ascertain the cost of a suitable sheet iron protector for the stove.

You advise, in connection with manual training, that when the boys get bigger they usually go to Sechelt Residential School, but you do not make it clear why such transfers should be made when a school is operating on the Reserve, and as Departmental instructions are to the effect that this is not to be done except where the home conditions warrant such transfers, manual training is being carried on successfully in other Indian Day Schools, even by women, this usually being done at the time when the girls are engaged in domestic science.

Mr. Gallagher's general reaction to the Inspector's observations would indicate somewhat of a defeatist attitude and resistance to change. In the absence of evidence to the contrary, the Department will, undoubtedly, accept the opinion of the Inspector as against that of the teacher.

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver, B.C.

re: Sliammon Indian Day School

I enclose herewith an account for supplies for the above School as recommended by the School Inspector. Mr. Gallagher advised me recently that he applied to the Department for a number of the articles included in the attached bill, but never received them. He is not in favour of plasticine for various reasons.

On a recent visit to the School, I made a careful check-up of the various matters mentioned by the School Inspector in his report on this School. Regarding the stove, the teacher states that a circulating heater is required, as he is afraid that the children will be burned when getting too near the present stove, which is often red hot. As these circulating heaters are practically unprocurable (in fact, any kind of heater is almost non-existent) I would recommend that a sheet iron protector be placed round the present stove.

With reference to the manual training, there is no room for this in the school, and in any case the boys are too small. When they are bigger, they usually go to Sechelt Residential School, where they are given manual training. In any event, the noise from a manual training class would prevent any other instruction at the same time. Another point which should be reckoned with is that the next teacher might be a woman in which case manual training would not be given.

With regard to the inspector's observation that the school should be made more attractive, Mr. Gallagher advised that all the children want to come to school. There is no difficulty in getting them there when they are on the Reserve, but the parents have to move around to make their living, and are forced to take the children with them. Mr. Gallagher, who has had long teaching experience, made the observation that it is quite common for a new inspector to make an adverse report on his first visit to a school so that he can claim improvement due to his efforts and inspections.

B/DH.

Sir:

I am receipt of a letter from Dr. J.C. Spencer of the Crosby Marine Mission regarding a school at Smith Inlet for the Indians of the Kwashola Band. The United Church has erected a small building to be used for church and educational purposes and have been discussing the matter with this office for about one year.

They now recommend that the Department supply 12 individual desks and the following school supplies:
- 1 doz 1st primers
- 1-2 doz 2nd primers
- 2 doz scribblers
- 1 doz no 1 drawing books
- 2 doz copy books no 1
- 2 boxes white chalk
- 1 " colored chalk
- 1 doz boxes oil crayons for coloring animals fruit etc.

They further recommend a grant of $30.00 per month to a lad named Walkus who was a pupil of the Alert Bay Residential school for about three years.

With regard to the above I am very much in sympathy with the plan as outlined above but I could not recommend Walkus as a teacher as he has not had any experience nor training along those lines. Smith Inlet is very much isolated and in order to get to it or away from it it is necessary to travel Queen Charlotte Sound which in winter is only fit for small craft on occasional days. It is one of the stormiest places on the coast of B.C.

This means that the people living there are practically cut off from the rest of the world for months at a time excepting for the monthly visit of the mail boat. There is no school near and there is no accommodation for any more children at the residential schools.
I am aware that the policy of the Department in every instance where possible aims to assist in the education of the Indian and I would be ready to recommend that the grant be given for one year as an experiment provided they had someone who was able to teach the children and do a little missionary work along with it, but I fear Walkus could not be relied on as a teacher although he would be better than none at all.

He would be cut off from all supervision so that he could get little help from either the Missionary Society, the Inspector of Indian Schools or the Indian Agent.

Your obedient servant

W.M. Halliday

Dear Miss Potter:

In reply to your letter of September 4th, reporting that some of the children in your school are suffering from a bad skin disease, I have to advise you that Mr. Ditchburn, Indian Commissioner, Victoria, has been requested to send you some supplies for their treatment. You will receive some sulphur ointment, some ammoniated mercury ointment and some chloroquine tablets. The tablets should be used for making a wash to cleanse the sores as well as possible before applying the ointment. Two tablets to one cupful of warm water will be about the right strength. If you will look between the fingers and on the front of the wrists of these pupils, you may find some little black specks in the skin or short black lines or tiny blisters. If you find these, you may take it that you have itch or scabies. The treatment for this is the sulphur ointment which should be rubbed in pretty thoroughly wherever there are spots and you may find it necessary to be patient if the cure is slow, as some cases of itch may have quite big sores as well, and these will take some time to clear up. If you do not find these little spots it may be better to use the mercury ointment but these are both good ointments and should benefit any sort of skin disease. The great thing is to get the spots pretty well cleaned up before you put the ointment on.

Mr. Ditchburn will also send you some absorbent cotton and gauze to use for cleansing purposes and dressings. I might also say that chloroquine tablets are one of the best applications for cuts and wounds of any kind that you can get.

I shall also suggest to Mr. Ditchburn that he sends you two gallons of cod liver oil and you will find it beneficial to give every one of your pupils a good spoonful after they have had their noon meal.
It will be appreciated here if you will send a little report every month stating how your pupils are getting on. You need not write much but we like to keep in touch with school pupils as much as we can.

Yours truly,

E.L. Stone, M.B.,
Director of Medical Services

Dear Sir,-

I have received official letter No. 156-46-1 dated June 27th from the Department stating that it has been decided to continue the services of Miss W. Sir,

I have to report in connection with the Indian Day School at Takush Harbour, Smith Inlet, B.C., that in order that the teacher's residence at this point should be habitable for next winter, considerable expenditure would need to be incurred in order to carry out repair work. In view of the fact that the number of pupils on the register is only seven, and the average attendance during the quarter ended March 31st was only 6.1, a condition due to the fact that the Kwashela tribe of Indians who own this reserve spend very little of their time there and are of a nomadic disposition, I fail to see that there is any justification for this Day School to be continued, especially in view of present conditions when it does not seem possible for authority to be granted for the necessary expenditure to be incurred.

The teacher, Miss W. Potter, is fully qualified and thoroughly imbued with the missionary spirit. She was placed there by United Church authorities, but I am of the opinion that under present conditions her energies are misspent and it would be better if the United Church authorities found a place for her elsewhere. The Inspector of Indian Schools, Capt. G.H. Barry, is also of this opinion and does not include this school in his itinerary.

The Kwashela Indians are not of the best type and need far more Police supervision than they have been getting for a number of years. Takush Harbour is in a more or less isolated location particularly during the winter months, and I have no hesitation in stating that it would be better handled if it were included in the Bella Coola Agency, as it is not so difficult of access from Bella Coola as it is from Alert Bay.

I would be glad to receive instructions in regard to this as soon as possible.

Your obedient servant,

[E.G. Newnham]

Sir:

I am in receipt of a letter from the Rev. Arthur Barner, Superintendent of Missions for the United Church of Canada, with regard to the school at Takush Harbor for the Kwashela Band. In his letter, he states as follows:

"I think that the only word which will describe the change there during the past eighteen months since Miss Potter took charge is 'transformation'. Of course there is not much change in the older people, and in the appearance of the village, but already there is talk of building better houses. It is in the children our hopes are centred, and certainly they are changed. I was astonished at the progress they have made with only five months schooling, which is the total the register shows."

Mr. Barner adds that at a meeting held on the evening of the 14th of February, Miss Potter made a request that the point of land to the south of the schoolhouse taking in twenty-five yards back to the west, measuring from the front of the school building be set aside by the people for school purposes, and it was agreed by all present that this be done. It was further requested at the meeting that Mr. Barner write to me to recommend to the Department to consent to this arrangement. At the present time Miss Potter has no privacy, and she would like to have this done, and also that she may have an opportunity to beautify the point of land. I would recommend that this be done. The point of land is only small, and they have plenty of land for their own purposes, and it will not be depriving them of anything.

Your obedient servant,

(W.M. Halliday)

Dear Mr. Ferrier,

I am spending a day here with Miss Smith, and I am quite sure that if you could have the privilege of seeing her, you would be convinced that this effort is well worth while.

In the first place, the courage and devotion of Miss Smith is very impressive. She has not been easy for her to stay here as there is still much work to do, but she does not complain at times. But she has no fear and she believes this to be her place.

In the second place, she is a real teacher. It is almost beyond belief that children who were entirely ignorant of English or any line of education should be able, with only five months of actual teaching, to show such advancement. Classroom work is done in drawing, not only in the three "K's," but in sewing, dance work, etc. Miss Smith has taught school every available day when the children were at home, often on Saturdays, holidays, but the people are unsettled in their ways and they go off here and there.

Of the third place, the spirit of the village is changing, and the men are talking about better homes. The hope in these "smoke houses" is very crude, and not much real advance can be made until the homes of the people change. But it seems as though they would never come until some one was willing to live in the village and act...
is an object lesson to the people.

In conclusion I must say that there were 11 children in the school today. I think they are under 7 but the training is good for the little ones and they pick up conversational English quickly at that age. They are all bright and show great interest in the school work.

With best wishes,

Faithfully,

Arthur Bower

Sir,

We have just been advised by Dr. H.D. Barner of the R.W. Large Memorial Hospital, Bella Bella, that Miss Winifred Potter who has been the missionary-teacher located at Takush Harbour, Smiths Inlet, has been ill, and it was necessary to remove her to the hospital at Bella Bella. Dr. Barner states in his letter it will be some time before Miss Potter is able to return to her duties and that there is some question that she may not return at all.

We regret very much Miss Potter's illness, and wish to express to the Department our appreciation for the very splendid work she has been doing as missionary-teacher at Takush but have felt for some time from the standpoint of the school it was not very satisfactory, owing to very few Indians living at this village during the past few years.

The conditions at Takush village have been reported on as very unsanitary and it is our opinion that these Indians should be moved out of this location. Most of them have been living on other reserves with friends on account of the condition of the village at Takush. We feel now that since it was necessary for Miss Potter to give up her work, this school should be closed entirely and an effort made to have the Indians located in a more suitable place. There are very few Indians in the Kwahela Band, and it is my intention to have the children of school age admitted to the Residential School as soon as arrangements can be made. This I feel would provide for the children and in the meantime an effort will be made to have the Band located in a more suitable village on this side of Queen Charlotte Sound.

I would suggest the Department take the matter up with the United Church of Canada with a view to having the Takush School closed entirely until such time as something definite can be worked out more satisfactory than at present.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

Dear Sir:

I have your letter of November 5th, in which you announce the decision of the Department not to re-open the school at Takush. I think it might be well, before accepting Mr. Indian Agent Todd's advice too hastily, for the Department of Indian Affairs to recall the circumstances which led to the opening of this school. While it is true that the group of Indians is comparatively small, ten years ago they were as untouched by Christianity and almost as unchanged in their habits of life and thought as when the Pacific was discovered. In that decade, Miss Potter has worked a miracle in the village. The very fact that the Agent can state that he is able to get all the children to go to Residential School (a fact which remains to be proven) is an evidence of the influence she has exerted upon the people.

As a matter of fact, this school has been carried on at a minimum of expense to the Department of Indian Affairs, because during the whole period that it has been in operation, the major portion of Miss Potter's salary has been guaranteed and paid by The United Church of Canada; and the property which the Agent talks about moving consists of a few school desks and a little equipment in the way of maps, charts, &c., and is a bagatelle compared with the investment that we have in the building, residence, and furnishings.

I would like to remind the Department of Indian Affairs that almost forty years ago the Methodist Church withdrew from a group of Indians at the head of Rivers Inlet on representations from Ottawa that the band was to be moved to a more suitable site, provided with houses for individual families in place of the long houses in which they were living, and given a school. Nothing has ever been done for them. They are as pagan to-day as they were a hundred years ago, - a disgrace to both the Government of Canada and the Church.

Will the Department of Indian Affairs give us some assurance that they really intend to move this group of Indians from Takush and settle them somewhere else? I do not question Mr. Todd's sincerity, nor is there any possible argument in regard to the advisability of what he recommends. I am not so sure that he will get the official support that he must have in order to carry out his plan. In the meantime, we cannot help protesting against this sum-
mary dismissal of a piece of co-operation, in which the Church, at least, has made such a large investment.

Yours very sincerely,

It is my sad duty to inform you that Miss Winnifred Potter, the teacher at Takush, died of cancer a few days ago in the Bella Bella Hospital. She had evidently been quite ill most of the summer but failed to report her illness to the doctor on the "Thomas Crosby." Her real condition was discovered almost by accident. Dr. Barner made a special trip from the Hospital and took her back with him. She lived only three or four days, and during the greater part of the time after she arrived at the Hospital was unconscious.

I am not sure whether or not the Department owed Miss Potter any money. If so, I wonder if it would be possible to have the cheque drawn in favor of the Board of Home Missions - or the Treasurer of the United Church. So far as we know, she has only one living relative - a sister, and our Superintendent in British Columbia will take responsibility for seeing that the money gets to her.

I would like to know whether or not it is the wish of the Department that we should appoint another teacher to Takush on the same terms. You will remember that a few years ago we fixed up the school and the house, so that the living conditions are now very comfortable, except for the extreme isolation of the place. I am under the impression, however, that both Captain Barry and Mr. Indian Agent Todd have been rather dubious about the value of the school work there. It would look as if we have a chance at the present time to do either one of two things: abandon the village entirely, or send in a new teacher, with the understanding that between now and the end of June the whole situation is to be reviewed. It is our conviction that the latter course would be desirable. It would seem too bad to sacrifice the results of the seven or eight years of sacrificial service which Miss Potter gave to this group of very needy Indians.

Yours sincerely,

KJB.MT

Kenneth J. Beaton

REPORT ON KWANKEWLTH AGENCY FOR MONTH OF MARCH 1937.

The Smiths Inlet Day School - The Mission started at this point by the United Church of Canada several years ago later started a day school. The Department assisted them financially for the building and furniture, etc. School is held when two or three children are in the village and the Department pays the Missionary $4.00 per teaching day when school is held. I have reported adversely on the continuation of this school. I should like to see this tribe move to a more desirable location but so long as the Mission continues I am afraid the Indians will not wish to go elsewhere. Their living conditions are beyond description.

Generally speaking, the Indians of the agency are provided with adequate educational facilities. There are some small villages where no day school is available, but these children are placed in the Residential school with the exception of those who cannot pass the medical examination.

I would like to say during the time I have been Agent I have noticed steady progress being made, and this is due to a great extent to the splendid co-operation between the teachers and the Department's school Inspector, Mr. Barry, who undoubtedly is an outstanding man in his profession.

M. S. Todd.
Indian Agent.
The day schools at Campbell River, Cape Mudge, and Alert Bay are in splendid shape and a real credit to the Department, while the Missionary schools at Village Island, Kingcome Inlet, Quatsino and Smiths Inlet which were built by various Missions with assistance from the Department are in fair state of repair, they are difficult to administrate. I feel the Department should own these schools and have full administrative powers as the buildings are on reserves. I would recommend if and when funds are available the Department should purchase any equity the Missions may have in these buildings to avoid any future complications which may arise between the Indians and interested parties.

Sir,

Enclosed please find the Quarterly Day School Return of the Smiths Inlet Day School for the quarter ended June 30th last.

The Department will please note there are three pupils attending this school, and that their attendance is not very regular. You will also please note the teacher reports in connection with Flora Walkus and Winnie Walkus that "drunken home conditions are against them".

For some considerable time I have recommended to the Department that this school be permanently closed. I can see no justification for keeping the school open, particularly when there are only three children going to school part time and with a condition in the village such as reported by Miss Pennington.

Takush village is very isolated and there is no way in which proper supervision may be given it. The Provincial Police are located at Ocean Falls, and can only make the occasional visit there. I have been aware for a considerable time that much drinking has been going on amongst this band, and owing to my inability to give these Indians proper supervision I have suggested closing the school and moving the village elsewhere.

Dear Sir:

I have recently had an opportunity to discuss with Capt. G.H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., and Mr. Indian Agent Todd the subject matter of your letter of September 28th.

Following the inspection of the Takush School on May 30th, 1937, Capt. Barry reported as follows, "From an educational point of view the paying of any sort of teacher here is a complete waste of money. I am forced to recommend that the school as such be closed at the end of June 1937 and not reopened." On receipt of this report I discussed the matter with Capt. Barry and concluded that an expenditure of any money on such a school, except possibly for a few school books to be used by the Missionaries could not be justified and in forwarding the report to the Department I concurred in the recommendations made therein. I should mention however, that Capt. Barry suggested that a fair degree of success might be achieved by the missionaries as welfare workers and that the Department might consider a small grant for this purpose. The Department, however, did not favorably entertain this suggestion. While in the north I met Capt. Barry by arrangement at Prince Rupert and, in view of the suggestions made in your letter, reviewed again the situation at Takush with him. The Inspector, however, could not for the reasons already stated and also that conditions had not changed at Takush, recommend that the school be continued.

On the 19th instant I met Mr. Todd at Alert Bay and also discussed the matter with him. Mr. Todd informed me that not more than two families were resident at Takush at the same time and then only for short periods. Further, that not more than four children were available to attend school and for a large part of the time the attendance would be down to two. Under these circumstances any social work would be so restricted that the grant suggested the Department should make could hardly be justified. I may say that I am inclined to agree with the views of the Agent in this respect.

The Department to my knowledge does not provide funds to carry out welfare work in the way suggested and I am satisfied would not consider the appointment of a field worker for such a small number of Indians. Should the Department have funds for social effort along the lines suggested we have other villages in the Province where the Indian Affairs Branch and the United Church could better establish such Welfare Missions.

Under the circumstances I regret I cannot recommend the grant suggested, but in order that the Department shall have an opportunity to consider the matter, I am forwarding to Mr. Hoey a copy of your letter to me of September 28th together with a copy of this letter for his information and whatever action the Branch wishes to take.

Rev. S. S. Osterhout, D.D.,
All Dominion Bank Building,
Vancouver, B.C.

Dear Sir,

I have a letter from Miss Margaret Pennington, B.A., who has been in charge of the little mission at Takush in Mr. Todd's Agency. Miss Pennington has had a Gall Bladder operation but is recovering and hopes to be ready for service by the end of October; she wishes to know if the Government is willing to continue its grant for the support of that work on the same basis as previously, which grant has been supplemented by our Board of Home Missions. The Government grant has been based on $4.00 a day per teaching day, in addition to supplying the teacher with fuel, and the Board of Missions paid at the rate of $40 a month throughout the year and assisted the Government in furnishing the teacherage.

While the report from the school would not seem to justify the continuance of that work because of the very low and irregular attendance at the school, nevertheless Miss Pennington has done a valuable piece of social service work in correcting irregular marriages and other unhealthy conditions in the community, the prevalent consumption of home brewed intoxicants, and we feel, at least I do personally, that that work should be continued until the amalgamation can be made between that small tribe and some other, preferably the O-we-kee-no tribe at the head of River's Inlet where there is a beautiful location for an Indian village with ample soil for gardens and a beautiful stream of pure water, whereas at Takush there is neither of these advantages. To close the school at Yakush and leave them at the mercy of human influences about them in the uninitiated would seem to be a very narrow-minded policy in dealing with the problem of the native people. It would save a small grant no doubt but at the same time it would result in the loss of the influence that we now have over this seriously decimated tribe of Indians who for many years were neglected by the Church if not the State.

I should be glad of a reply from you indicating your recommendation in the matter.

With kind regards,

Sincerely yours,

SSO/AM

"S.S.Osterhout."

P.S. Your Inspector, Capt. Barry, intimated when in conversation with me on a former occasion that while the school itself does not justify the Government Grant made, nevertheless he would recommend a small sum say $250 or $300 for the service rendered by Miss Pennington, along moral and social lines.

If the grant is to be continued, Miss Pennington is anxious that some firewood should be provided at an early date as it is usually done earlier in the year than this.
She also complains about the condition of the cookstove, that it is rusted so badly that it is no longer usable for baking. I presume the lining of the oven has rusted out or the firebox burned out beyond her ability to repair.

Dear Mr. Hoey:

Re: Smith's Inlet School

I have your letter of November 26th. I can only say that I concur most heartily in the conclusion to which your Department has come. As far as I am concerned, I do not expect that the matter will be reconsidered, unless, of course, it should happen that the school population increased.

This is a band of Indians which is exceedingly small, and just as backward and depraved, and I think that both the Department and the Church is wasting money there.

There are, however, one or two questions which emerge. The first is regarding the salvaging of certain buildings and equipment, which both the Department and the Church have at Smith's Inlet. The building is really a joint residence and school. I do not suppose that it can be moved. Would the Department consider the purchase of it from whatever funds are available, either of the Band or of the Department, in order to provide better housing, which is certainly needed by those people?

Then, the desks and other property of the Department, and certain furniture which is the property of the Church, might be stored, or moved to some place where they would be of more service.

In that connection, may I ask if you have received a recommendation from the Commissioner in regard to opening a school at the head of Rivers Inlet? I understand that the Lumber Company has purchased standing timber from the Owe-kee-no Band and that as part of the purchase price they are going to erect a certain number of good houses. I am advised that it would be very much in the interests of these people if a teacher could be appointed. I think we should be prepared to co-operate with the Department if it saw its way clear to erect a school and contribute towards the salary of the teacher, as it has been doing at Smith's Inlet.

Personally, I think it would be a very much better investment of funds and of personnel. I shall be glad if you will let me know what the Commissioner has in mind for this tribe.

Yours sincerely,

Dear Sir:

I notice that the Department cheque for the teacher's salary at Takush, Smith's Inlet for the June quarter is only $28 and for only seven days teaching.

Allow me to say that I visited this point a few weeks ago and found Miss Potter, the teacher, absolutely alone, the Indians having moved out with their families as soon as the fishing season opened.

Moreover Miss Potter was just recovering from a severe illness which has rendered her almost helpless for the time being.

Under these circumstances it is not surprising that the returns came so far short of the number of teaching days required to earn the full salary for the quarter.

I submit these facts in extenuation and leave to the Department to decide if it is not a case calling for payment of the full allowance for that quarter.

Yours very sincerely,

Kenneth J. Beaton

August 26, 1939.

Dear Sir,

As instructed in your letter of February 11th last, No. 15-6-7924, I proceeded to Smiths Inlet Indian Day School at the end of the current school year and removed all the Government property to the warehouse at the Agency, Alert Bay.

It was necessary to pay freight on these goods from Margaret Bay to Bone Bay; this I paid for out of my Travelling Expense Account and put through Voucher No.123 in favour of myself covering this amount. A complete inventory of everything in the school was made, including all school supplies and equipment as well as the furniture, etc., in the teacherage. There was a small amount of drugs on hand and as the teacher had left previous to my arrival, it was not considered safe that certain of these drugs be left in the teacherage, and anything which might be used by the Indians detrimental to their health was destroyed, as it was not considered worth while moving these small quantities in a few bottles.

Anything that was safe to leave in the teacherage and which could be used again was left there and the key to the teacherage was turned over to the Rev. Peter Kelly of the United Church Mission Boat "Thomas Crosby", who is keeping same until he can remove certain articles belonging to the Church and the building is disposed of.

Since the school has been closed I have had some correspondence with the Rev. W.P. Bunt, B.A., B.D., Superintendent of Missions for the United Church at Vancouver at the request of the Rev. Peter Kelly with a view to disposing of the Church's equity in the school and teacherage at Smiths Inlet. Mr. Bunt has informed me he is under the impression the United Church of Canada would accept $150.00 for their equity in the buildings rather than try and tear them down and move them elsewhere.

As the Department are aware, the teacherage was built some years ago jointly by the Department and the Church, and in my opinion the value of the buildings at the present time would be upwards of $700.00, particularly as the freight costs so much as they are located in such an isolated place. The Church has spent quite a lot of money at different times which the Department know nothing about, and now that they are willing to accept $150.00 cash for their equity rather than attempt to move it away, I would recommend that the Department pay the United Church of Canada the amount of $150.00 for their equity, and the funds to be taken from the "Housing Appropriation" as allotted to this Agency.

Insofar as the Department's equity is concerned, I would recommend that they transfer it to Chief George Walkus of the Kwashela Band to be used for a home for his family. In this connection I would like to point out the Chief's home was burned about a year ago and he is badly in need of a residence.
For the Department's information, the teacherage and school are joined together but are in reality two separate buildings, and it is my intention that the school should be given to another Indian family who have no home, with the understanding that they move it on to another lot in the village site.

I hope the Department will agree to this arrangement as it will permit me to help these Indians who have no homes to live in. If the Department approves of this, would you kindly forward me a cheque in the amount of $150.00 so that I may conclude the deal with the United Church of Canada, and at the same time advise me if you are prepared to release the Department's equity in favour of the Indians of the Kwashela Band to be used for housing accommodation. An early reply would be appreciated.

In regard to the equipment, it is my intention to use all the school supplies that are suitable for the second classroom which we are now establishing at Alert Bay. The furniture for the teacherage is being kept intact for the moment but it is possible some of it can be used elsewhere, but before doing anything the Department will be consulted further.

Your obedient servant,

(M. S. Todd)

September 12th, 1939.

The school and teacherage at Nattika Inlet, B.C., which is owned by the United Church of Canada has been abandoned at the end of the last school term, because of the small attendance. These buildings were built by the United Church of Canada.

In the summer of 1938 the Department of Indian Affairs agreed in conjunction with the United Church to remove the buildings on a fifty-fifty basis, the Department's share not to exceed $500.00. The total cost of these alterations amounted to $600.00. However, the Department paid no more than the agreed amount of $500.00. Since then the sum of $100.00 has been expended in further repairs. The present valuation of these buildings estimated by our Indian Agent is $700.00.

The Indian Commissioner of British Columbia recommends that the buildings be purchased from the United Church of Canada at a cost of $150.00 and that they be made available to homeless Indian families and charged against our Housing Appropriation.

The accompanying memorandum to the Council recommends that authority be granted to purchase the equity of the United Church for the stated sum of $150.00.

Dear Sir:-

With further reference to your letter of 13th October, 1939, regarding our purchase of the equity of the United Church of Canada in the Indian Day School and teacherage at Smith's Inlet, in which you requested to be advised of the name of the Indian family who would use the building not occupied by the Chief, I would quote from Mr. Indian Agent Todd's letter of the 26th ultimo on the subject, as follows:

"In connection with the School, this building is attached to the Mission House, and as the Indians have no place in which they can hold service when the 'Thomas Crosby' calls, or a place to hold meetings of their own, they asked that this building be set aside to be used for that purpose, and I agreed with them that this was a good idea. The building will therefore be used for Church services and as a hall for meetings when I visit the village."

As was previously understood, Chief George Walkus is occupying the Mission House proper, on the understanding that he keeps it clean and in good state of repair.

Yours faithfully,

Sir:-

From our conversation of yesterday I know this arrangement is satisfactory and that you will recommend it to Ottawa for the approval of the Department.

Sir:

I have your letter of Feb. 4th, 8-P-2, with reference to Miss Geohegan's appointment to the Songhees School. She understands that her appointment is only temporary, but she is doing very well, and it would be too bad to replace her just now. She is not altogether without qualifications, as her course of studies in England, qualified her as an assistant Teacher there.

The attendance still keeps up, she likes her work, and the children like her. However, in accordance with your request, I will make an effort to obtain a fully qualified teacher, but as you say this will be difficult to do, at the salary offered. I have spoken to two, since the appointment of Miss Geohegan and both of them turned the proposition down. Should I find one, it is doubtful whether he or she would hold the position permanently. There is danger of them giving it up as soon as something better turned up, which would be bad for the children and for the school.

Personally I would recommend that no change be made at least for this quarter, and if by that time, her (Miss Geohegan's) success is not satisfactory, then somebody will have to be gotten. At any rate three months gives her a chance to show what she can do. If she makes good, then I think the Department will confirm her permanently. I would therefore ask you to report to the Department.

1. That she is not entirely without qualification.
2. That at the present she is doing very well.
3. The difficulty of obtaining a fully qualified teacher just now at the salary offered.
4. Give her a trial for the quarter.

With best wishes,

I remain,
Sincerely yours,
(Signed) John F. Silver.

Dear Mr. Lomas:

In accordance with my promise to you, I have been looking for a teacher who would be willing to take over the duties of teacher to the Songhees Indian school, on April 1st, and after diligent search I am of the opinion that Miss Josephine Hindle, at present living in Victoria, would prove the most satisfactory. While Miss Hindle does not actually hold a teacher's certificate, she could I am sure obtain one without much difficulty. She has completed three years of High School work in the Province of Nova Scotia and on many occasions filled in at the schools in Halifax for Teachers who were off for one reason or another. She is well acquainted with the work that is required at the Songhees school, as often during Miss Geoghegan's term, she went down to the school with her, and saw that was being done. She is acquainted with the children, knows where they live, etc., which to my mind is of great help to the teacher. I would therefore respectfully submit the name of Miss Hindle to you, and if you think fit ask you to recommend her to the Indian Department at Ottawa. If you will send any information to Miss Hindle to my address, I will see that it reaches her. She is a clever girl and I feel that she will make good.

Dear Sir;

With reference to the attached correspondence, I have the honour to recommend the permanent appointment of Miss Margaret Burt, 3078 Orillia Street, Victoria, B.C., as teacher of the SONCHEES Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, of which school she is at present the substitute teacher.

She is also in possession of Summer School Certificates for Primary Work, and for Writing, obtained in 1930; and Art, and Indian & Rural Problems obtained at the last Provincial Summer School held this year.

Her experience has been as a substitute teacher in the schools of the Saanich Municipality, and for the past five months as substitute teacher in the Songhees Indian Day School. During her time in the last school she has brought the children on well, and very much improved the general standing of the school. I have no hesitation in recommending her permanent appointment at a salary of $80.00 per teaching month - less 10% for the current financial year, and with $2.50 per teaching month for janitor work.

I know that in the case of vacant teaching positions in the Catholic Indian Schools in Bishop Murray's Diocese, he would like to be consulted after I have made a tentative selection. I am perfectly certain that the same is true with regard to Bishop Bunoaz. I am informed that it is unlikely that Archbishop Duke would wish to interfere in any way with one of the other Catholic Bishops, though he would like to be consulted with regard to appointments in his Diocese.

EXTRACT FROM REPORT OF INSPECTOR G. H. BARRY ON HIS
INSPECTION OF THE SONGHEES INDIAN DAY SCHOOL.
Date of Inspection April 7, 1936.

Name of Teacher: Miss Margaret Burt Age 26

Miss Burt was trained at the Victoria Normal School. She holds a B.C. Class Certificate. She also holds a number of certificates from the Provincial Summer School, Victoria. These include Primary Work and two for Indian and Rural Work. She is in her fifth year here. She has had no other experience with the exception of some substitute work in Saanich.

Miss Burt has a good manner with the children. She is certainly very much liked by her pupils. Her attitude towards her work is very good. I have previously reported that Miss Burt is a little weak in the actual presentation of the lesson, in that the aim is not clear enough, and more or less left to chance. Miss Burt taught a lesson in elementary Number Work for me during the present inspection. This lesson was well presented, the Blackboard being particularly well used. She is doing as well now as she is likely to do. I have suggested that she attend the Provincial Summer School again this year, taking Primary Work and some such course as Technique of Teaching.

The teacher's control of the children is a little weak. She has improved in lesson technique since my last visit.

I am sorry that I am unable to sum up the work being done here as better than when I last inspected just six months ago. The school may be said to be doing fairly satisfactory work in an elementary sort of way. Its general standing may be classed as "Fairly Satisfactory".

I am not very satisfied with the work being done at this school, though I know that Miss Burt is doing her best to get the children on. The B.C. Achievement Test results in themselves show very weak teaching.

EXTRACT FROM LETTER OF INSPECTOR BARRY DATED APRIL 9th, 1936, ACCOMPANYING THE ABOVE REPORT.

The Department had requested an inspection of this school near to May 1st. I am leaving for Bella Coola and Prince Rupert on April 18th on the close of the Easter vacation. The teacher is a nice girl who is doing her best. Her control is very weak. Some of the Indians are absent in the hop fields in September and fruit picking in June.

In my Survey of Small Indian Day Schools dated January 6th 1940 my report on this school will be found on Page 4. I there suggested that it might not be in the best interests of the Indians to close the school in either September or June. Now that it has been decided to close the school in September, it would appear foolish to keep it open in June when there are even fewer pupils than in September.

I beg to attach herewith in duplicate a copy of a letter received from Miss Bertha Blue, Teacher of Songhees Indian Day School, and also a Certificate from Dr. A.F. Barton, which will be self explanatory.

In this regard I might say that Miss Blue has been far from well all winter, but managed to stick it out at school when most girls would have been off on sick leave. You will please remember that Miss Blue taught all through the summer holidays last year, which was really too much for her although she didn't realise it at the time. After the Songhees school closed for the summer she went to Christie School and taught there until Sept. 1st. last.

I would recommend that Miss Blue be given the time off she asks for, to take effect from the end of the Easter holidays up to May 8th, which would be three weeks, plus the week's holidays she will have at Easter. Dear Mr. Moore:

I am enclosing a certificate received from Dr. Barton, on March the sixth. Because I am very interested in my present position I hope I shall be able to take a month's rest, then come back and carry on teaching here.

Everything favourable I should like to leave as soon as possible. Realizing the difficulty in obtaining a substitute for a full month, I thought perhaps if I could find someone to substitute for me either two and a half weeks immediately preceding, or the two weeks following Easter, it might be easier managed that way.

MEMORANDUM

To: The Indian Commissioner for B.C.

From: The District School Inspector.

Re: Songhees Indian Day School

Following complaints received by Mr. Indian Agent Moore from parents on the Songhees Reserve concerning the lengthy visits of Father Bradley at the above mentioned school, I called on Bishop Hill in Victoria on March 4th and discussed the matter with him. Previous to my visit to His Excellency I called at the Songhees School and examined the register which indicated that the Reverend Father Bradley called at the School on the following dates: January 30, February 2nd, 3rd, 4th, 9th, 10th, 11th, 12th, 13th, 20th, 24th, 25th, 26th and March 2nd. The register showed that Father Bradley had remained at the school for an hour and one half on February 24th, one half hour on February 25th, one hour and twenty minutes on February 26th and one hour and one half on March 2nd. The length of his visits on the other occasions was not given. The register also indicated that previous to the month of February Father Bradley had visited the school occasionally. Bishop Hill felt the visits of Father Bradley could be less concentrated and said that he would take the matter up and I considered at the time that the matter was satisfactorily concluded.

However, Mr. Indian Agent Moore has forwarded to me a copy of the minutes of the Songhees Band meeting held on March 4th from which I quote: "The teaching of religious Instruction in the Songhees Indian Day School was the subject of discussion by the meeting. The members felt that this Instruction should be limited to the time authorized by the Department and no longer. At present, the Priest calls during school hours and takes the pupils from the class to teach Catechism. It was explained, by the Chief, that the teacher had little or no control over the actions of the Priest and could not, very well, refuse the pupils leaving the class-room to receive Religious Instruction. After considerable talk it was suggested by the Council that a School Board of three members be appointed, which might be of assistance to the teacher in this regard, as well as on other school matters. The agent explained that they must understand that any board elected would have to be approved by the Department which would, no doubt, set out its functions and duties. It was, eventually, decided to nominate three members -- the result of which follows:

Indian Affairs. (RG 10, Volume 6416, file 847-1, part 1)
1) Richard Albany—proposed by Chief Percy B. Ross and seconded by Austin Albany.

2) Mrs. Sam Joseph—proposed by George Cooper and seconded by Arthur Albany.

3) Johnny Albany—proposed by Sam Joseph and seconded by Frank George.

It will noted that this meeting was held prior to my visit to Bishop Hill and it is assumed that the matter has been satisfactorily settled.

However, the Band is apparently requesting permission for the formation of a school board of three members to assist the teacher on school matters. Although such a board with limited powers might be advisable at a later date it is felt that in view of the recent dissatisfaction it would only lead to further trouble and it is recommended that if the Department is requested to give permission to form such a board that approval should not be given at the present time.

R.F. Davey,
Dist. School Inspector.

Indian Boy Wins Prize For Painting At Exhibition

A painting by a 13-year-old Indian boy, of the Songhees Indian Day School, who received no art instruction, won the Memorial Scholarship of the B.C. Indian Art and Welfare Society at the National Art Exhibition which opened at the Provincial Museum today.

The boy, Leonard Thomas, received the award from Education Minister W. T. Strath, who officially opened the exhibition in the presence of native schoolchildren and members of the society at 3 this afternoon.

The exhibition, sponsored by the society to encourage native Indians in developing their native crafts and arts, will be hung in the National Art Gallery in Ottawa for a period of two weeks.

Some of the latest works of 19-year-old Judith Morgan, Kitwanga, Skeena River, who for two successive years won the "Memorial Scholarship." She did not take part in the contest this year.

Miss Morgan had never taken a lesson in art until the beginning of 1947. Since then her work has steadily improved; this year's paintings this summer will be hung in the National Art Gallery in Ottawa for a period of two weeks.

School children awarded prizes in the art contest today were Leonard Thomas, Songhees Indian Day School, Memorial Scholarship; Sherman Murray, 1st prize junior group, Alberni Day School; Erma Gallic, 2nd prize junior group, Alberni Day School; Joy Clutesi, 3rd prize junior group, Alberni Day School; Donald Barker, 1st prize senior group, Songhees Indian Day School; Charlie Sam, 2nd prize senior group, Kwakiutl Indian Day School; Frank Lucas and Elmer George, tie, 3rd senior prize, Christie Indian residential school.

Ina Unthoff, artist, was judge in the competition.

The buildings consist of a schoolhouse, placed on a cement basement, in which wood is kept, and in which the furnace is placed. The furnace supplies hot air to the schoolroom. There are two toilets with regard to which I have previously reported on a number of occasions. These are being kept in a much better condition. The reason that they require such consistent attention is that there are no dug out pits here. The receptacles are made of galvanized metal and are in fact small round bath tubs. They rest on the cement floor of the toilets. The Department will easily understand why I have asked that they be emptied regularly. I would recommend that these toilet receptacles be emptied ONCE A MONTH during the ten teaching months that the school is in session, AND THAT NOT MORE THAN $2.00 BE PAID MONTHLY FOR THIS SERVICE TO THE INDIAN WHO DOES THE WORK, the contents of the receptacles to be buried in a pit to be dug at a place satisfactory to the Indian Agent. There has been a certain amount of correspondence between the Department and the Indian Agent, Mr. Graham, with regard to this matter. I would ask that such correspondence be reviewed in the light of this report and recommendation, and the necessary authority and instructions issued to Mr. Indian Agent Graham. The $10.00 might well be taken from the fees allowed for Janitor Service to the teacher if there are no other funds available, but this girl could not do the necessary work of course.

There is a broken gutter in front of the school which certainly needs attention this summer. The buildings belong to the Department. They require painting as soon as there are funds for such purposes. Part of the walls of the schoolroom need kalsomining. The ceiling does not.
Ottawa, May 30, 1935.

Sir:

Mr. Inspector Barry, in a report on his recent inspection of the Songhees Indian Day School, has drawn attention to the need of the receptacles in the toilets being regularly cleaned out. He recommends that these toilet receptacles be emptied once each month during the ten teaching months that the school is in operation during the year and that not more than One Dollar ($1.00) be paid monthly for this service to the Indian who does the work. The Department will approve of you arranging with an Indian to empty the receptacles in the toilets at least once each month during the next school year. You may forward certified vouchers, in triplicate, at the end of each quarter, for the amount due the Indian who performs this service.

The Inspector states, further, that there is a broken gutter in front of the school, which needs attention. You may have the necessary repairs carried out, keeping the cost as low as possible.

Mr. Barry states, also, that part of the walls of the schoolroom need kalsomining. If this would not involve much expense, the Department will approve of you arranging to have the work done during the coming summer holidays.

You should forward itemized accounts, in triplicate, properly certified, covering the cost of repairing the gutter and kalsomining the walls, only, of the school.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
Secretary.

On visiting the Songhees Day School my attention was drawn to the unsatisfactory state of the furnace which was smoking very badly. I examined the same and found it very badly worn, so got an estimate on the repairs which amounted approximately to $1.00. I would be pleased if the Department would sanction these repairs being done.

Your obedient servant,

January 10th, 1938.

Sir:

When visiting the Songhees School I found the furnace was smoking very badly, so I took my coat off and went at the furnace very thoroughly, and found that it was completely burnt out, and that the smoke was going all through the hot air vents.

A short time ago I had one of the holes I saw patched, but apparently the whole inner lining is burnt out which would mean practically a new furnace, with the exception of the bowel.

On talking the matter over with the teacher, she thought that a stove in the school room would be very much more satisfactory as it would heat up quicker than the furnace, which takes a considerable time every morning before the school room is warm.

On going in to the school at 10 a.m. I found all the children in their overcoats, and the room filled with smoke.

I would like to recommend that a stove be purchased for this school, which would mean having a hole cut in the chimney and a thimble placed in same to carry the stove pipe, and the cost should not exceed $30.00. I also think that the stove would be more economical on the fuel.

Your obedient servant,

H. Graham

Dear Sir:

The attached application from Indian Agent Graham, for authority to expend $30.00 on a stove for the Songhees Indian Day School, is recommended for favorable consideration.

It is very doubtful if a furnace should have been installed in this school, which is a one-room building and could be adequately heated by box or drum type of heater. The alternative would be to repair the furnace, which would cost considerably more and would not be as economical on fuel as the type of heater commonly used in the one-room Public Day Schools and some of our Indian Day Schools in this Province.

Capt. G. H. Barry, Inspector of Indian Schools for B.C., is absent on inspection duties, and his recommendation in this matter has, therefore, not been secured. I am reasonably satisfied, however, that he would approve of the purchase of a suitable stove for heating the Songhees Indian Day School instead of repairing the furnace unit now in need of extensive overhaul and repair.

Yours faithfully,

D. M. Mackay,

Sir,

This amount will be deducted from her salary cheque for the December quarter.

You will be good enough to explain this matter to Miss Quigley.

Sir:

I am writing on behalf of Miss Josephine Hindle of the Songhees Indian Day School in this Agency, she had made an appeal to me for a month's wages in advance. She informs me, and I know it to be a fact that her brother is seriously ill in the Hospital and she unfortunately will have to foot the bill. As you know the Day School teachers are paid quarterly, therefore she at present has almost two and a half months salary coming to her.

I appeal to you on most compassionate grounds to do what you can in the matter, Miss Hindle is a most valued teacher and I can assure you she would not have made the appeal unless it was urgently needed.

Yours obediently,

Ottawa, January 12, 1932.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 4th instant, enclosing copy of a communication from Miss Josephine Kindle, teacher of the Songhees Indian Day School, in which she applies for six months' leave of absence, as from February 1st, next.

In reply I have to say that the Department will approve of Miss Kindle being granted the leave of absence requested by her. It is noted that you have discussed this matter with Mr. Inspector Barry and that he has a substitute teacher to carry on the work during the absence of Miss Kindle. I would request that you forward the name, qualifications, etc., of the substitute teacher. Salary will be allowed the substitute at the same rate as was paid Miss Kindle, viz., $50 per teaching month. Miss Kindle should prepare a report covering the attendance and days taught by her during the current month and forward same through your office, when payment will be made of the salary due her up to the date she begins her leave of absence. It is hoped that the substitute teacher will be engaged in time to take charge on February 1st, next.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Acting Secretary.

Ottawa, January 16, 1932.

Sir:

I have your 15/3/23593 of the 7th instant, enclosing copy of a communication which you received from School Inspector Barry, recommending the appointment of Miss Margaret Burt as substitute teacher to replace Miss Josephine Hindle, the teacher at the Songhees Indian Day School, who has been granted six months' leave of absence, from February 1st, next. The qualifications which Miss Burt possesses have been noted, also that the priest in charge of the Songhees Reserve has recommended Miss Burt for the position of substitute teacher.

The Department will approve of the appointment of Miss Burt to teach during the absence of Miss Hindle. The salary allowed her will be at the same rate as was paid Miss Hindle, viz., $80 per teaching month. Please advise Miss Burt accordingly and arrange with her to take up duties on the date mentioned above.

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 23rd ultimo in which you advise the Department that the Songhees Indians have voted an expenditure of $2500.00 from their funds for the purpose of erecting a building on the new reserve suitable for school and Church purposes.

In reply I beg to say that the Department appreciates the attitude of the Indians towards the education of their children and would like to see an up-to-date school with modern improvements erected on the reserve. The sum of money voted by the Indians would be ample to erect a building which would provide accommodation for all the children who at any time should attend, but such a building would not be suitable for church purposes, where it is presumed that accommodation would be needed for at least 75, which is about 50 per cent of the total population. For school purposes I may say that there should be provision in the building building for 250 cubic feet of air space for each child and 16 square feet of floor space and it is thought that accommodation for at least twenty children should be provided.

Having the above facts in view the Department would like you to confer with the Indians and give this matter further consideration, at the same time stating what kind

Ottawa, Aug. 14, 1912.

Mr. Pedley,

No school has as yet been erected on the new Songhees Reserve, although the Department has been in communication with the Agent since October of last year. The Indians voted the sum of $2500.00 from their funds for the purpose of erecting a building to be used for school and church purposes. The Department did not look with favour upon the erection of a building for the joint purpose in so much as church accommodation would have to be provided for about 75 people and accommodation for 20 would be ample for school purposes. The matter was again taken up with the Indians with a view to having them come to a decision. The Agent after considerable delay has again reported, stating that the Indians are willing to spend $3000.00 for a Roman Catholic Church and school combined, but for a building to be used for school purposes only they think $1000.00 would be sufficient.

The residences erected on this reserve are modern and
and the school-house should be in keeping with them. We have plans of a school-house for 25 or 30 pupils which would be appropriate for this reserve and the erection of a building according to these plans would cost about $3,000.00.

I would recommend that the Department put up the school-house and obtain the authority of His Royal Highness the Governor General In Council to take sufficient funds from the capital of the band to meet the cost of construction. It may be remarked here that these Indians had a good school on the old reserve and they individually obtained the benefit from the money which was received from the sale of the building. I think, therefore, on this account and the need that there is for adequate school accommodation that it would be quite proper to take this course. This is now their second year on the new reserve and during this time the children have been deprived of education.

The undersigned would, therefore, recommend that authority be given for the expenditure of this sum from the Capital funds of the Band (which amounts to $10324.46) in accordance with the provisions of the 59th Section of the Indian Act.

The Agent after considerable delay again reported that the Indians were willing to spend $3000.00 for a Roman Catholic church and school combined, but for a building for school purposes only they considered $1000.00 would be sufficient.

The residences erected on the new reserve are modern and the school-house should be in keeping with them. Plans have accordingly been prepared for a school-house to accommodate 25 or 30 pupils at an estimated cost of $3000.00.

Section 89 of the Indian Act provides that money can be taken from the Capital funds of a band with the sanction of the Governor in Council without the consent of the band.

Acting D.S.G.I.A.
On a Memorandum dated 19th August, 1912, from the Acting Superintendent General of Indian Affairs submitting, that it is desirable in the interests of the Indians on the new Songhees Reserve, British Columbia, to erect a school building for the accommodation of the Indian children, and the Department of Indian Affairs has had plans of a school building prepared to accommodate 25 or 30 pupils at an estimated cost of $3,000.00.

The Minister, therefore, recommends that authority be given for the expenditure of this sum from the capital funds of the Band, (which amounts to $10824.46) in accordance with the provisions of the 89th Section of the Indian Act.

Dear Sir:

Kindly inform me if I can add the following extras to the present specifications of the proposed school on the Songhees Reserve, Esquimalt, B. C.

**WEPPING DRAINS**

I notice no mention of tile weeping drains around the exterior walls of building. Taking into consideration the position of school and the nature of the soil, I think it will be very difficult to keep a dry basement without a weeping drain laid lower than the basement floor. The approximate cost would be $25.

**WATER**

To run a water supply from the main to the school-house. This is essential, both for toilets and wash basin or sink. The approximate cost would be $30.

**WATER CLOSETS, etc.**

I notice on the plans two (2) water closets crossed off, unless these closets are included, I am afraid it will tend to very unsatisfactory sanitary conditions; but if the water closets are included, I would suggest that the position shown on the plans should be changed so as to keep the plumbing work a little closer and thereby curtail the cost of the same.

There is no sewer drain in the neighborhood, so if we install the closet fixtures, we will also have to build a septic tank, the approximate cost of fixtures, tank, etc. would be $300.

**WASH-BASIN OR SINK.**

I would recommend a wash-basin or sink in basement for the
procuring of water for school purposes (washing hands, etc)

I think a sink would meet the requirements better than a wash-basin. The approximate cost would be $40.88

LIGHT

There is no provision for electric light, neither is there any electric power in the neighborhood at the present time, though the service of the City of Victoria runs close to the school property, and service may be given at any time to the immediate vicinity.

I would suggest that the school should be wired in readiness to receive the above service, also that by wiring the school new all wires could be concealed in walls, partition, etc.

The approximate cost would be $150.00

Yours obediently,

C., as I am having considerable difficulty in getting the work completed. I have warned the Contractor time after time, and drawn his attention to the progress of work clause, but all to no purpose. I allowed him to stop the work for a few days on account of sickness, but since his recovery, he has done very little to complete the work.

There is not more than two (2) or three (3) weeks work to do to complete the school, if only the contractor would get reasonable strength of men on to do it, but before I take extreme measures to make the contractor come to time I would like to know what the agreement was between the Contractor and the Department when the contract was let to him; if there was no time limit in the agreement, I am afraid we will have to rely on the "Progress of Work" clause in the Specifications.

Enclosed you will a copy of correspondence between me
and the Contractor on this matter which was sent by registered mail.

Yours obediently,

Mr. A. Lockley.

Dear Sir:

Re. the Songhees Indian School-house, Esquimalt, B. C.

The School-house is now completed and ready for the opening (with the exception of the furnishing and dry closets, which are mentioned in another letter).

I have had considerable trouble getting the work completed according to the Plans and Specifications, and to my own satisfaction. The contractor Mr. J. Robinson has been in hospital twice during the construction of the school, but even when he was well and able to attend his business, he displayed very little interest in the work. From the very beginning of the work to the completion, I have had reason to make him take out bad work; all the window frames and door frames have been taken out and re-made and re-fixed twice, also the steps (back and front; also back porch).

When I saw it was impossible to make him complete the work in a given time, I took what I thought was the next best step in the interest of your Department, and that was to compel him to do the work in the best possible manner.

I am straightening out one or two small claims for
extras with Mr. Robinson, and when complete, I will send the final certificate to your Department.

Dear Sir:

Re. the Songhees Indian School-house now under construction by you on the Songhees Indian Reserve, Esquimalt, B. C.

I beg to notify you that unless the said School-house is completed in its entirety, including the grading of earth around the school-house, etc., and the following alterations made to some of the work already fixed into position by you; by Friday next, the eleventh (11th) day of July, 1913.

I will employ men provide material and finish the work and charge the same to you.

The following items must be altered as they are contrary to Plan and Specifications; Stair landing at the top of main entrance, stairs to be 1\(\frac{1}{2}\)" flooring as specified, joints to be painted with white lead before laying; the treads on all stairs to be as specified viz: 2" - those you have fixed measure 1- \(3/16\) thick instead of 1- \(5/8\"); the transom lights over the main windows must be three (3) lights as shown on Plan.
The stairs leading to the back entrance will have to be rebuilt and made with a longer run to reach the grade level; the surplus earth at the back of the School-house will have to be moved and placed where directed, the outside entrance step to basement to be taken as the highest point where grading so as to keep the basement dry in wet weather, at present the entrance step is about two feet below ground level.

All the gutters at the ends and the joints are leaking very badly; these must be made water-tight.

There are several other items that I have called the attention of your foreman to.

Hoping you will have this work attended to at once and save any further delay or trouble.

Yours truly,

Mr. H. Lockley,
Inspector.
