I also went out to the School to lay out the dry closets and paid another visit on the completion of the same.

The number of visits I made to the School far exceeded what the Department asked me to make (viz. one visit each week), but the work was so unsatisfactory that constant watch had to be kept on the contractor at all times; not only had I occasion to condemn the work actually on the School, but I had to condemn the work under construction at the contractor's workshop. It was a very difficult matter to make the contractor work to the plans and specifications, though with strict supervision I believe the Department have got a first class job and a little more than was specified, also the extras that were allowed, come below my estimates that were given to the Department about Feb. 21st, 1913.

The above list of official visits cover about twenty-nine (29) weeks (including the dry closets) which amounts (at the rate mentioned by the Department) to two hundred and ninety dollars ($290.00). I have omitted all incidental expenses and have allowed only for the actual weekly visit.

Dear Major MacKay:

With further reference to my letter of October 31st concerning the supply of school desks for the Songhees Indian Day School, Cowichan Agency, I may say that I have examined the tenders submitted by Mr. Cline, Messrs. Clarke & Stewart, and Messrs. Anthes-Tait.

For 2 only, school desks No.2, and 4 only, rear sections No.3, plus Sales Tax and f.o.b. Victoria, the following would appear to be the competitive bids:

Messrs. Clarke & Stewart $41.02
Messrs. Anthes-Tait $40.92
Mr. Cline $39.74

It should be noted that the tender of Mr. Cline is the lowest by a small margin but the desks are not the Crown school desks quoted on by the other firms, though Globe desks may be considered just as satisfactory and well up to Government standard.

It is, of course, quite immaterial to me which firm receives the order, though I should point out that for a number of years Crown desks have been supplied to our schools.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.

Sir:

In explanation of the attached Voucher 170 amounting to $4.35 in favour of The Melross Co., Victoria B.C., for emergency repairs to the Songhees Indian Day School, I beg to advise that a very few days before the end of the School term—May 30th, ultimo—I visited it and noticed one of the front windows broken. I asked the Teacher about it & how it happened and when, and she replied that one of the girls accidently put her elbow through it when getting out of her seat at her desk just the day or so before and that as she was expecting me to call she did not write. As the term was finished two days later, I considered it better to have the glass put it right away rather than apply to the Department for the necessary authority, as the resulting delay might mean further damage or even entry into the school by unauthorized persons. There was no one on the reserve who could put in a pane of glass that size and so I had to have it put in by glazer.

Trusting that my action in this matter will be approved,

Yours obediently,

The Secretary,
Indian Affairs Branch,
Ottawa.

(R.H. Moore)

October 17, 1942.

Dear Sir:

I enclose herewith letter dated the 15th instant received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore, advising that owing to employment of a large number of Indians in the shipyards at Esquimalt, in the vicinity of Songhees Reserve, that the attendance at the Indian Day School has increased to such an extent that it will be necessary to transfer desks from the East Saanich Day School where the number is in excess of the requirements, and also to improve the heating system of the School in order to make more floor space available.

The total cost of these changes would amount to about $50.00 according to Mr. Moore's estimate. In view of the limited supply of suitable stoves available, it might be difficult to get one at $45.00. I would recommend approval of the application if funds can be provided. Please let me have a reply by airmail.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

October 15th, 1942.

Dear Sir:

During a recent visit to the Songhees Indian Day School, I found it full to overflowing with eight pupils there more than we have desks. The increase in attendance at that school can be explained by the fact that so many of the Indians from other reserves are working in the shipyards in Victoria and residing on the Songhees Reserve, the result being that their children attend the Songhees School. It will be necessary to get another 8 medium sized desks and I would recommend that we take them from the Saanich School where we have about 10 desks too many for the number of children we have attending, or are liable to attend for some years to come. If authority is granted to move these desks I can have them taken in by the East Saanich Freight Service and delivered to the Songhees School, at an approximate cost of $5.00.

With the extra desks required for the Songhees School it will naturally mean more crowding and this will mean that we will have to procure the Circulatory Heater which we have spoken about on several occasions for use in this school. By using a heater of this type it will mean that the pupils can sit much closer to it than they can to the ordinary stove which is at present in use, without fear of getting overheated or burned. The greatest advantage however is the fact that the heat is circulated around the room evenly. I would recommend that the necessary authority be granted for this heater at an approximate cost of $45.00.

I would also recommend that the present stove be used in the basement of the school which will have to be used for the boys doing their manual training work. Your early approval for the above services will be appreciated.

Yours obediently,

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

Ottawa, December 6, 1912.

Mr. Pedley—

The contract for the erection of the new school building on the Songhees Reserve is being forwarded for execution. Sometime ago we wrote to the Agent with regard to inspection of this building. Mr. Robertson, however, lives at Duncan Station, which is 40 miles from Victoria and the new reserve is only four miles from the city by the Esquimalt and Nanaimo Railway. Mr. Robertson suggests that someone living at Esquimalt be appointed to inspect the work. This would be most convenient, but an inspector could easily go once a week from Victoria. I would ask you to name a person who may be engaged for this work.

[Signature]

OFFICE OF THE DEPUTY SUPERINTENDENT GENERAL,
OTTAWA, February 7, 1913.

The Secretary,

Necessary action may be taken for
the appointment of Mr. A. Lockly, Thorburn Post Office,
B. C., as inspector of the work on the new school build-
ing on the Songhees Indian reserve during its erection.
He will be expected to make a visit once a week and will
be paid $10.00 per visit and actual travelling expenses.

D. S. G. I. A.
Sir,

The Department has under course of construction a day school building on the Songhees Indian reserve, four miles from Victoria.

I would be pleased if you would undertake the inspection of this work. You should visit the building once each week and report progress to the Department. You will be allowed $10.00 for each visit and your actual travelling expenses.

I am sending you under separate cover a copy of the plans and specifications; also blank progress certificates. Payment will be made to the contractor on the work progresses up to 90% of the value of work performed and material on the ground upon receipt of certificate from you.

It might be well for you to communicate with Mr. J. Robinson & Son, Contractors, Fraser Street, Victoria, and ascertain definitely that the work is in progress before you make your first visit.

Your obedient servant,

[Signature]

Asst. Deputy and Secretary.

Ottawa,
April 16, 1943.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing letter from Indian Agent Moore requesting authority to expend $146.00 for the construction of cupboards and a manual training bench for the Songhees Indian Day School. The amount requested appears large, especially in view of the fact that the quarterly return shows only 12 boys enrolled. The oldest of these is 13 and consequently, in view of their age, very little manual training could be given. The return also shows that there are only 2 girls over 14 years of age. All the others are much younger and have not yet completed Grade 4. Taking everything into consideration, the Department does not see any necessity for spending the amount of money mentioned at the present time. If a small cupboard is needed for the books it should be possible to either build or purchase this for $25.00 to $35.00.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Department of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith application received from Mr. Indian Agent Moore for authority to expend $146.00 for the construction of cupboards and a manual training bench for the Songhees Indian Day School, these being necessitated by the considerably increased attendance due to an influx of Indians to the neighbourhood of the Reserve as ship yard workers during the present emergency.

If funds could be provided for the purpose, I would recommend approval of the application subject to some revision of the construction of the manual training bench, as I consider that two 6 ft benches would be preferable to a 12 ft. bench placed against the wall as intended by the Agent.

KT

D.M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Enc.
Indian Commissioner for B. C. P. O. Box. 70. Vancouver, B. C.

Please refer to your letter above noted and previous correspondence regarding cupboards and work bench for the Songhees Indian Day School.

Since Mr Coleman's inspection of this school on February 10th, last when the matter of these cupboards was brought to his attention, I have not been informed whether or not there is any chance of them being supplied, and as the Teacher is continually asking me if I have heard anything about them, I would be obliged for any information you may be able to give me regarding same.

(R.H.Moore)

Dear Sir:

With further reference to the matter of increased attendance at the Songhees Indian Bay School, I wish to advise that to make room for the extra desks it will be necessary to move a make-shift work bench fastened on the south wall of the school and used by the boys for manual training and wood carving.

It is planned to have a new work bench put up in the basement of the school along one of the walls and below a window which the boys can use for their manual training work; this will be much better than having them do this work in the school room. A new bench will have to be provided, made out of three 2"X12"X12' planks plus the material for the stand or legs. A cupboard will also have to be provided in the basement to hold the tools and manual training supplies, and also some general supplies which are piled in corners and on the floor at present.

Then in the school room itself, we will also require two cupboards to store school supplies, and books. At the present time these supplies are piled in the east end of the building where the church altar is, not under lock or key and a temptation to anyone who is subject to lifting things.

These improvements have been talked about for the past two years, but on account of the war I felt that we could get along for the time being. Now, however, with the increased attendance it has put an entirely different light on the question and something must be done to protect our own supplies and give additional accommodation. I got an estimate of the cost of all (3) cupboards, and work bench complete and installed amounting to $46.00. I would advise that authority for this be granted, and recommend that the work as outlined be approved.

P.M. MacKay, Esq.,

Vancouver, B. C.

Ottawa,
June 13, 1944.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner, P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

I have your letter of the 8th instant, enclosing letter from Indian Agent Moore recommending the installation of flush toilets at the Songhees Indian Day School. In view of the information contained in Mr. Moore's letter and also in the second paragraph of your own letter, the Department approves of this installation and you may make the necessary arrangements, keeping the cost as low as possible.

Such requests as the above place the officials at head office in a very awkward position. The expenditure will probably be reasonably high and yet the matter has been only brought to our attention several months after the estimates for the current fiscal year have been submitted and approved by the Minister. I think you will readily realize our position and I suggest that in preparing their estimates for the fiscal year 1945-46 all Indian agents in British Columbia should be definitely advised that they must anticipate their requirements. In submitting these they should attach detailed information regarding any extraordinary expenditures that they may consider necessary, in order to enable the Department to make an intelligent decision on such requests. In view of the increasing demands on our appropriation it is simply impossible for us to continue indefinitely approving expenditures for which no request has been made when submitting estimates.

R.A. Hoey,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

I enclose herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of June 5th, in connection with the proposed installation of flush toilets at the Songhees Indian Day School.

In view of the fact that this school is situated within a densely populated area, I am of the opinion that favourable consideration should be given to this matter; but before proceeding to secure an estimate of the cost I would appreciate receiving the Department's reaction to the proposed installation.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Encl.
The Songhees Band has passed a Resolution asking that the outside toilets be done away with at the Songhees Indian Day School and that flush toilets be installed there. Apparently there is a most offensive odor from the present toilets all through the spring, summer and fall months and also during the winter when the wind blows.

As this school is situated right in the middle of a Municipality I believe that it would be in the best interest of all concerned if favourable consideration could be given to this request. If it is turned down by the Department I have been informed confidentially that every public body in Esquimalt is going to give it all the publicity possible, which in my opinion should be avoided if at all advisable.

I have not made any effort to get prices on just what the approximate cost of two flush toilets would be installed as I felt that I had better refer the matter to you to see if you think there would be any use in my doing so for if the Department is opposed to toilets of this kind in schools (as was evidenced when they were refused for St. Catherine's) then it would just be a waste of time. However, I would like to state that we have flush toilets in the Nanaimo I.D. school and there has never been any trouble with them since I came to this Agency. Kindly advise in this regard.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

January 5th, 1948.

Major D.H. MacKay, Indian Commissioner for B.C., Vancouver.

I wish to report that during a recent visit to the Songhees Indian Day School I found that the water pipe was leaking down in the basement and running all over the floor. I was unable to determine the cause of the leak or its exact location and consequently had to get a Plumber to go out and look the situation over and see just what the trouble is.

Apparently the stop and waste at the entrance to the property is not functioning at the water main and there is not a stop and water inside the building at all. The drain from the basement needs attention and a thorough cleaning out although the extent of this cannot be determined without doing some digging.

I was unable to get the Plumber to commit himself on just what the job would cost without I authorised him to expose the entire pipe from the main to the building and also the drain pipe. He did say however, that the minimum cost would be $18.75 and if he had to do much digging and install any new pipe it might run to $25.00 or $30.00. I got the impression however, that he felt that with the installation of the two set of stop and waste fixtures that the difficulty would be solved, plus the cleaning of the drain. At all events the matter is quite urgent and I would ask for the necessary authority to have the work which is considered necessary attended to right away.

(R.H. Moore)
Indian Agent.

March 8, 1946.

R. H. Moore, Esq., Indian agent, Duncan, B.C.

I have your letter of March 5th in connection with the proposed installation of electric light in the Songhees Indian Day School, and would point out that the matter was dropped for the reason that we were awaiting further information from you, some of which has still not been received. It is noted that the school building is more or less a community centre for the reserve, which, to me would indicate that the largest percentage of electricity would be used in the evenings for social gatherings rather than for school purposes, in view of which it is likely that some arrangement would have to be arrived at whereby the Indians of the Band assume responsibility for part of the electricity costs.

Please let me have your views in this connection and give an estimate of the approximate monthly cost of the electricity for the building. I may say I have been unable to find any information in this office in support of your statement that the building in question is owned by the Department, and as I have always been under the impression that it was owned by the Indians themselves I would appreciate whatever information you have available on this point.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Further to my letter of the 5th instant and your reply above noted I would advise that the band has already as per resolution of January 25th, 1945 agreed to an expenditure of $40.00 as part of the cost of the installation of the lights in this school and which I feel is a reasonable proportion of the cost of installation for the band to be called upon to pay in view of the fact that the building is so far as I can determine the property of the Department, and while it is noted that you are unable to find any information to support my statement - which after all, was given to me by the Indians - I would suggest that the matter be referred to the Department and definite information received regarding this debatable point.

I did not intend to give you the impression that the building was used frequently as a Community Centre other than for the holding of entertainments by the school children, nursing classes, and possibly for band meetings of four or five times per year. As it stands at present it is one or two individuals of the band that assume responsibility for the lighting of the building by coal oil lamps or a wire strung from the adjoining house.

It is difficult to give you an estimate of the approximate monthly cost particularly during the winter months, but from April 1st until the end of October the minimum rates of $2.50 per month should pretty well cover. However I do not expect that the total annual expenditure would exceed $50.00

R. H. Moore
Indian Agent.

With reference to your letter of the 18th instant, the Department will allow an amount of $200.00 for installation of electric lights in the Songhees Indian Day School. I presume the Agent will take the necessary steps to make certain that a satisfactory job is done and that there is no fire hazard.

Philip Phelan,
Chief, Training Division.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources, Ottawa.

I am forwarding herewith Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of February 13th, 1945, together with a copy of my reply and subsequent correspondence in connection with the proposed installation of electric lights in the Songhees Indian Day School building.

It will be noted that the estimated cost of wiring the building, including lights and fixtures, is $200.40, that the Band are prepared to contribute $40.00 towards the cost from their Band funds and that the annual cost would be approximately $50.00.

In view of the use made of the school building outside of school hours for nursing classes, entertainments for the children, etc., and the resulting fire hazard from the use of coal oil lamps, I consider that it would be advisable to proceed with the installation of electric lights. It is too late to proceed with this matter during the current fiscal year and although no specific provision was made in the 1946-47 estimates, it is hoped that funds can be made available.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

Duncan, B. C.

January 25th, 1945.

We, the undersigned, Chief and Councillors of the Songhees Band of Indians owning the Reserve situated at Craigflower, in the Cowichan Indian Agency, in the Province of B.C., at a council summoned for the purpose, according to the rules of the Band, and held on the said Reserve, this 25th day of January, A.D. 1945, in the presence of the Indian Agent for the said Reserve, representing thereat the Minister of Mines and Resources for the Dominion of Canada;

Do hereby for ourselves, and on behalf of the Indian owners of the said Reserve, request that a sum not exceeding $40.00 (forty) Dollars, be paid out of money standing to the credit of this Band, for the purpose of paying a part of the cost of wiring the Songhees Indian Day School, for electric lighting, with four lights in the school room, 1 light on the porch and one in the entrance hall. One light in the basement and one in the turn of the basement stairs, a total of eight light outlets and 4 plug-in outlets. It is estimated that this work will cost approximately $160.00 plus a charge of $10.00 for connecting with the power line.

In view of the fact that this school building belongs to the Department, we feel that the full cost of this work should be a charge against the Indian Affairs Branch, but to expedite the matter as well as to show our interest in the welfare of the children, we will assist to the amount stated.

Signed and sealed in the presence of:

Indian Agent

Please refer to your letter, date and file number above noted, reference the proposed installation of electric light in the Songhees Indian Day School.

In this regard I may say that the question appears to have dropped after your last letter, as nothing further was done until a few weeks ago that I happened to notice the stoppage in proceedings.

I wish to attach hereto in duplicate a quotation from a very reliable contractor covering the cost of complete installation as stated in the Band Resolution of January 1945 and consisting of 14 lights in school room, 1 light outside front door, 1 light in hallway, 1 light in basement and 1 light at turn in basement stairs, plus 2 double plug-in outlets in school room.

The principal reason for lights in this school is to give better lighting to the children. During the dark winter months it is extremely difficult for the pupils to see their work books, except on the row of seats along the window.

Furthermore the school building is more or less the Community Centre for the Reserve; meetings and entertainments being held there with coal oil lamps borrowed from the various Indian houses.

I consider this installation most necessary and would recommend that it be carried out as soon as funds can be provided.

R. H. Moore

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Moore's letter of March 17th in connection with a proposed expenditure of $25.00 for clearing the grounds of the Songhees School.

It is unfortunate that this matter has been left so late in the fiscal year, but if funds are available I would recommend that an accountable advance of $25.00 be forwarded to Mr. Moore by air mail on the understanding that the work would be performed and the advance accounted for prior to March 31st.

For D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
Duncan, B.C.,
March 17, 1947.

Major D. W. Neckey,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B.C.

I should like to have your permission to expend the sum of $25.00 in cutting brush and clearing two or three patches of stumb pine growing on the grounds of the Songhees Reserve School. Unfortunately, I am unable to get anyone to do this work unless they are paid in cash, owing to the fact that they would have to lay off their own regular job to do it. There are no old people on the Reserve who are receiving relief and who might be used to do this work, which leaves it entirely up to the young men who are regularly employed.

If I could have an accountable cheque sent me by Air Mail I could have this work completed in a few days and before the end of the current fiscal year.

R. H. MOORE
Indian Agent.

I beg to submit, herewith, a copy of a letter received from Dr. Grey with particular reference to a screen for use at the Songhees Indian Day School which he had the opportunity to buy some time ago and which he thought would be of great value to the school from an educational point of view. I have seen this equipment and know that it has been put to use on several occasions at the school during recent weeks. It is as good as new and is worth many times what Dr. Grey purchased it for and I would recommend that the Department be good enough to give favourable consideration to the question of purchasing it.

On the off chance that funds may be available for this purpose now, I beg to attach, herewith, Voucher No.236 in favour of Dr. Grey for the amount stated.

The other account, amounting to $20.00, in favour of Dr. Grey, covers the cost of a cupboard for books, etc., which was authorized some time ago for this school and which we were unable to buy or to have made at any thing near the price which we managed to get this one for from Dr. Grey, who had it in his office in Victoria.

Dear Mr. Moore:

When the Salvation Army was selling out their equipment, I noticed they had a 9 by 12 foot Glass Beaded Screen on Roller. This had cost them $150.00 wholesale - I purchased it for $35.00 and lent it to the Craigflower School as a screen for educational movies.

I also purchased and lent to the school a large cabinet which has a glass top and glass doors. This measures about 6 foot 6 inches in height and approximately 42 inches in width - it has been used for supplies. The cost of the cabinet, at auction, was $20.00.

I would like to sell these to the school if the Department would care to purchase them.

I am enclosing an account, in quadruplicate, which you might care to endorse if the purchase is authorized.

Yours very truly,

"T.W.A.Gray"

Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines & Resources, Ottawa.

Re: Songhees Indian Day School

Attached are two vouchers covering work completed on the above mentioned school to permit the use of the basement of the building by a Boy Scout troop which has been organized in conjunction with the operation of the school. This work was authorized by this office in order that the work might be completed in time to permit this activity to get under way at the beginning of the present calendar year. This office is aware that the Department favours this type of activity.

The payment of these vouchers amounting to $68.33 is recommended.

W.A. Maclean
for W.S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.

enclos.
Mr. W. S. Arneil,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Post Office Box 70,
VANCOUVER, B. C.

Re: Sonohes Indian Day School.

Please refer to previous correspondence regarding the above noted school and use of same for the Boy Scouts as authorized by the Department.

This authorization has caused a condition in this school which has to be corrected immediately and that is the removal of the oil drum from the basement of the building to a frame or fixture outside the building so that a pipe, for gravity feed, may be connected with the heater direct from the oil drum or tank outside, thereby eliminating - almost entirely - the possibility of fire. This installation is in accordance with Fire Marshall regulations and fire restrictions in the municipality of Esquimalt.

The installation, including the supplying of the steel stand for the drum, piping and labour, will be forty-eight dollars and five cents ($48.05) and I would ask that authority be given at an early date.

I should have mentioned that the fuel oil has been kept in a 45 gallon drum in the basement up to the time that the Scouts took it over as a meeting place -- which required that the old wood burning stove be set up in the basement.

R. H. Moore
Superintendent
Cowichan Agency.

Re: Songhees Indian Day School

I wrote you on January 21st regarding the use of the basement of the above named building by a Boy Scout troop which has been organized in conjunction with the operation of the school. Superintendent Moore has now written (reference his letter of February 8th enclosed) asking that authority be given for the removal of the oil drum from the basement of the building to a frame or fixture outside the building, to eliminate the possibility of fire.

I concur in Mr. Moore's views that this work should be done immediately and an expenditure of $45.05 is therefore recommended, covering the cost of a steel stand for the drum, piping and labour.

You will note that the installation is in accordance with Fire Marshall regulations and fire restrictions in the municipality of Esquimalt.

During a recent visit to the Songhees Indian Day School I received a request from the teacher and pupils that the Department consider favourably the request for a sewing machine to be used by the girls during the time allotted for sewing at the school.

I might say that Miss Frith has had excellent results along these lines during the past year and the pupils appear very keen and are anxious to get as much instruction as possible in Domestic Science of this nature.

I would therefore recommend that the Department be good enough to arrange to have a four drawer Singer Sewing Machine shipped direct to:

Ottawa, October 29, 1940.

Dear Sir:

The Director, when reviewing the estimates for the fiscal year 1941-42, was anxious to learn from me if we had at any time canvassed the possibilities of establishing a consolidated school that might serve the purpose now served by the Squamish Indian Residential School.

Dr. McGill has himself visited the Squamish district and is reasonably familiar with the location of the school, the Indian homes on the reserve and the distances between these homes and the institution.

It has been decided to abandon our building program for this year at least and with an annual increase in the Indian school population of approximately 300 pupils it is altogether likely that we shall have demands from a number of Indian residential schools in the outlying sections of the Dominion, asking for increased enrolments. These requests, if granted, would of course mean an increased appropriation for the payment of per capita grants and I am not at all sure that such an increase can be secured.

However, if we could establish a day school at Squamish to take the place of the existing residential school, we would be in a position at least to increase our per capita grants at other schools to the extent of the amount saved at Squamish. I appreciate very fully the fact that this is a rather delicate matter and one that may have to be approached cautiously. It might be well, therefore, to discuss the matter with Inspector Barry and probably with the church authorities and the

Major D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B. C.,

Sisters in charge of the school. It would appear, in view of our war effort, that it is going to be increasingly difficult to secure the funds necessary to maintain our present educational program. Dear Major MacKay:

Some weeks ago you asked me to make a brief survey of the pupilage of the Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools to determine whether or not the children involved could be accommodated in a Consolidated Day School.

The attached nominal rolls of the children now attending the Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools have been prepared for me by the Reverend Sister Mary Alix, Principal of the schools in question. The following are summaries which it is hoped will be of assistance to you and the Department in coming to a decision in this matter.

The Squamish Day School pupils attend the Residential School classes and as far as academic work is concerned, receive exactly the same education.

At present there are twelve boys and fourteen girls in attendance at the Squamish Day School, while in the Residential School there are twenty-seven boys and thirty-four girls. The classification of these children by grades is as follows:

| Grades | 1 | 2 | 3 | 4 | 5 | 6 | 7 | 8 |
|--------|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|---|
| **Day School** |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |
| Boys   | 0 | 2 | 1 | 1 | 1 | 0 | 0 | 1 |
| Girls  | 3 | 1 | 1 | 5 | 0 | 1 | 0 | 1 |
| **Residential** |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |   |
| Boys   | 10| 2 | 0 | 5 | 4 | 4 | 2 | 0 |
| Girls  | 18| 4 | 1 | 5 | 5 | 0 | 0 | 1 |

It will be seen from the above that the children are fairly evenly distributed between the grades, with the majority of the Residential School pupils in the primary grades.

It is of extreme importance in considering the possibility of the establishment of a Consolidated Day School to take the place of the present Day and Residential Schools to consider the home conditions of the children at present on the roll of the Squamish Indian Residential School. The following tabulation will set forth in a brief manner the information given on the nominal rolls:

|                     | Boys | Girls |
|---------------------|------|-------|
| 1. Both parents dead.| 3    | 0     |
| 2. Father dead.      | 3    | 6     |

From the above it will be easily seen that at least half of the boys and about one-third of the girls need Residential School care in any case.

The following tabulation will give a clear picture of the location of the homes from which the Residential School pupilage is drawn:

| Location          | Boys | Girls |
|-------------------|------|-------|
| Burrard #3        | 5    | 7     |
| Squamish Inlet    | 13   | 19    |
| Squamish Mission #1 | 1    | 3     |
| Musqueam          | 6    | 2     |

Briefly, I may say that Burrard #3 Reserve is located in or near the Lynn Valley District, some eight miles from the present Squamish Residential School. There are good roads joining these places. The Musqueam Reserve is located near Point Grey, some fifteen miles from the present Squamish school, on the Vancouver city side of Burrard Inlet. Transportation of the Musqueam children to a Consolidated School at Squamish would involve far too great a distance and also the crossing of the new Lions Gate Suspension Bridge. Squamish River Indian Reserve is located at the head of Howe Sound, some forty miles by water from North Vancouver. Where Squamish is given as the location of the home, it should be understood that this includes the local Reserves in the vicinity of the present Squamish Indian Residential School.

Attached you will find a roll of ten children discharged from the Squamish Residential School during the past year, all these children were fifteen years of age or over. Two were in Grade 4, two in Grade 5, three in Grade 6, and three in Grade 8 at the time of discharge. These children would appear to have received on the average a satisfactory training in the academic subjects.

I regret that it is quite impossible for me to recommend the establishment of a consolidated improved Day School in North Vancouver to take the place of the present Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools. Two main reasons may be given for this conclusion:

1. It would be practically impossible to arrange for the satisfactory transportation of the children involved when the distance to the Musqueam and Burrard #3 Reserves are taken into account. In no system of consolidation could the children from the Squamish River Reserve be included.

2. A very large proportion of the children at present receiving their education at the Squamish Indian Residential School are exactly those who, from the nature of their home and family conditions, must of necessity receive their education at a Residential School.

I trust that the above information will be of assistance to you and to the Department in coming to a final decision and that the present Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools may be allowed to continue to function as such.

Yours very truly,

[Signature]

Gerald H. Barry,
Inspector of Indian Schools.
Dear Sir:

I have to refer to Mr. Hoey's letter of October 29th regarding the suggestion that a consolidated, improved day school be established on the north shore to take the place of the existing Squamish Indian Residential and Day Schools.

The possibilities in this connection have been carefully considered and the whole question fully discussed with Inspectors Barry and Coleman.

Inspector Barry's report, together with a sketch plan of the Reserves served by the existing arrangements, is attached.

Owing to the widely scattered character of the Reserves from which the pupilage is drawn, the proposed consolidation would not be practicable. Moreover, a large percentage of the children would, in any event, require residential school care because of unfavorable home and family conditions.

It will be recalled that the establishment of a Day School on the Musqueam Reserve to care for those children for whom there is no room in the Squamish Residential School has been provided for in the 1941-42 Estimates on Departmental instructions.

I would recommend that the existing arrangements be continued.

Yours faithfully,

D.M. MacKay,

October 18, 1922.

Memorandum.

Mr. Scott:

I have to report that at the time of my visit to the Squamish Boarding School, B.C., I learned that the Sisters were conducting a class for day pupils who are living on the reserve. As you have been informed, these Sisters are in dire financial straits, and I advised Sister Mary Amy to submit a quarterly return for the day school. This report is now to hand, showing an enrolment of 15 with an average attendance of 12.75.

I wish to recommend that we pay a teacher's salary to the principal of the Squamish Boarding School for this day school activity. A similar arrangement has obtained in the past at the Pine Creek Boarding School in Manitoba. Funds can be found from our Vote, as we have closed a few day schools because of lack of attendance.

Ottawa, November 25th, 1927.

Sir,

I beg to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 18th instant, with reference to the September quarter salary cheque for the teacher of the Squamish Indian Day School. In reply I beg to say that I find that this was addressed, in error, to Sister Mary Alix, North Vancouver, B.C. The cheque left here on October 17th. Please make further inquiries from the postal authorities and, if you are unable to locate the cheque, you should write me again.

Your obedient servant,

Russell T. Perrier,
Supt. of Indian Education.

C.C. Perry, Esq.,
Indian Agent,
415 Winch Bldg.,
Vancouver, B.C.
Sir:

Your obedient servant,

[C.S. Perry]

The Secretary,
Department of Indian Affairs,
Ottawa, Ont.
Sir:

I beg to refer to Departmental letter dated November 25th., No. 167-2-3, with reference to a missing cheque which left Ottawa October 17th. addressed to Sister Mary Alix, North Vancouver. In this matter I beg to say that enquiries have been made and it does not appear that the cheque has been received. In this connection I beg to transmit herewith a letter dated December 6th. signed by Rev. Sister Mary Amy, Principal of the Squamish Indian Residential School, bearing on this matter. The Postal authorities at North Vancouver are not able to trace it.

Your obedient servant,

(C.C.Perry)
Indian Agent.

Dear Sir:

Referring to your letter dated Dec. 1st, stating that the salary cheque for the Squamish Indian Day School was mailed to Sister Mary Alice, I beg to say that all the letters addressed to the Sisters are handed to me first, and I distribute them to the respective owners. I do not remember having had in hand any letter coming from Ottawa bearing Sister Mary Alice's address.

Besides, I searched my account books and enquired at the bank if they had cashed the above mentioned cheque and they said they did not. Should same have been destroyed or some other way the future will tell, as all the cheques are returned to the one who has issued them.

Thanking you for the trouble you have taken, I remain, dear Sir,

Yours truly,
[Signature]

Ottawa, 17 January 1947.

Major D.M. MacKay, Indian Commissioner,
P.O. Box 70, Vancouver, B.C.

With reference to your letter of the 7th instant, the Department approves an expenditure of $87.40 to purchase glass and wire screening for the Squamish Indian Day School.

Bernard F. Neary,
Supt. of Welfare & Training.
Indian Affairs Branch, Dept. of Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ont.

I am enclosing Mr. Indian Agent Taylor's letter of January 2nd and enclosures referred to therein in connection with window glass required for the Squamish Indian Bay School building and a proposed expenditure of $80.00 for screen wire to protect the windows.

The building in question is apparently a two-storey structure, the upper floor of which is used for classroom purposes and the lower floor as an auditorium.

It is recommended that an expenditure of $7.40 be authorized for the purchase of window glass, and if funds are available that Mr. Indian Agent Taylor be authorized to purchase the screen wire at a cost of $80.00.

D. M. MacKay,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.
D. M. MacKay, Esq.,
Indian Commissioner for B.C.,
Vancouver.

The glass listed on the attached requisition is required to replace broken windows in the Auditorium of the Squamish Indian Day School.

When I inspected the School in November, I noted many broken panes in this building and the Principal requested that the Department purchase replacements.

Since then several panes were smashed during one lunch hour by persons unknown. The police were notified but have been unable to locate the culprits.

I advised the Principal that more effective daytime supervision of the school property was necessary, as it seemed that someone should have been aware that such destruction was occurring in daytime.

To prevent recurrence of previous continual expense for replacing window panes, it will be necessary to place heavy wire screening of small mesh over the windows.

The cost for wire will be around $80.00 and if funds are available, I will submit details and quotation. Will you please advise?

(H. E. Taylor),
Indian Agent.

Telegraph Creek
Oct 12th, 1906

J. Calbreath Esq.,
Acting Indian Agent.

Sir:

Having being informed that the Indian Department are willing to make a grant of $30 a month towards an Indian School if established at Tahltan, could not this grant be made towards the school at this point. Under the Provincial School Act none living in the Indian mode of life are admitted to the schools, but here there are 17 Indian children attending.

The parents of the children are very anxious that they should secure an education, and nearly all have promised to leave their children in Town during the winter, while they go of hunting.

The children are bright and intelligent, and are anxious to learn; they readily obey what they are told to do, and are very regular in their attendance.

Kindly refer this communication to the Indian Agent and oblige.

Yours Respectfully,

R.H. MacJames.
British Columbia.

Indian Office,

Victoria, June 10th, 1907.

File No. 300,429.

Sir,-

With reference to my letter to the Department of the 26th of October last, No. 454. A. S., with respect to the urgent request made by the Indian parents living at Telegraph Creek, Cassiar Agency, B. C., for an Indian day school grant, in the usual sum of $300.00 per annum, for the Indian children of the locality, I have the honor to forward herewith a copy of a further communication, of the 20th ultimo, received from the Acting Indian Agent, Mr. Callbreath, asking that steps be taken at the earliest possible date to have provision made for the payment of such a grant in order that the teacher referred to, Mr. R. H. MacInnes, be induced to remain in the district.

In connection with this request I may state for the Department's information that, as pointed out by Mr. Callbreath, there are only four white children at present school for white children at Telegraph Creek. Were a grant made by the Department

The Secretary

Department of Indian Affairs,

Ottawa, Ont.
Department for the Indian children of the locality. Mr. MacInnes could be induced to remain and by drawing the salary allowed by the provincial government for a teacher at Telegraph Creek as well as the grant now asked to be provided by the Department he would thereby be in receipt of sufficient remuneration to provide a living for himself. As the Indians are very anxious to have their children educated and as, if Mr. MacInnes leave the district considerable difficulty may reasonably be expected to be encountered in providing the services of a special teacher for the Indian children, due in a large measure to the remoteness of the locality from the centres of civilization and the difficulty and uncertainty of access and consequent high cost of living, I would strongly recommend that, if at all possible to do so, provision be made immediately for the payment of the salary of a teacher for that point.

I have the honor to be

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir:

I beg leave to submit the following report for the month ending October 31st, 1911. Most of the Indians with the exception of a few of the aged and sick are away to their winter hunting grounds. Only a few were able to leave their children with relatives at the village and at Telegraph Creek, consequently the attendance at both schools has been small, but there is just a possibility that more may attend after Christmas when those of the hunters who have been successful in their fur catch can afford to leave their families in the village for the few months of the remaining winter.

I think it would be a mistake to close the school as was suggested by my predecessor. Those who are fortunate in being able to attend are advancing in a very encouraging manner and both of the teachers are making every effort to bring them forward. In my opinion a boarding school in the village under the management of the Church of England Mission with a married man and his wife to look after the girls would be the only reasonable solution to the problem of educating the rising generation of the Tahltan tribe, the larger percentage of whom are bright and intelligent and quick to adapt themselves to the White man's ways. A technical branch in connection with the school would be of great benefit to them.

I am sir,

Your obedient servant,

Sir,

I have the honor to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of the 5th inst no 3004291, with reference to the establishment of a night school for the Indians and in reply I beg to say that when I mentioned the matter to the Department before, there were several young men who seemed to be anxious to learn and as that was the only way that I could see of affording them an opportunity of going to school I made that suggestion thinking that possibly arrangements could be made to have the school teacher at Telegraph Creek run a night school for them when they were here as they are always around in the spring time and some of them remain in during the winter, but I certainly would not be in favor of having a school in connection with any religious teaching, the time should be spent entirely on their studies with occasionally a lecture on honest principles and their duty to each other, that is something that they can be made to understand.
I am thoroughly convinced that it is of little use to try to educate the Indians unless we do something to eradicate their superstition. I find that it is the practice of the missionaries to always treat them as children and depend upon someone to think for them. What right have we to expect any intelligence from them as long as they are treated in that way, it certainly seems to me that it would be much better to let their minds and reason expand as they grow to be men and women so that they could be regarded as such, instead of always being little children.

I find that the Tahltan Indians are getting more obstinate and harder to deal with all the time; this is likely the last time that I shall have a chance to give my views to the Department and I make these remarks through sympathy for them.

I have the honor to be,

Sir,

I have to acknowledge the receipt of your letter of October 16th, #300429-1, re change of masters at the Telegraph Creek Day School. In reply I beg to state that this School was built by the Provincial Government for the education of White children resident in Telegraph Creek and the masters in charge are nominees of the Minister or Superintendent of Education for the Province. These Masters at the close of the June quarter go out to Victoria or Vancouver for the Summer vacation and we never know who is to take up that duty until the party arrives in the last week in August.

As the grant allowed by the Provincial Government was too small to support a Teacher, The Department of Indian Affairs gave a grant of $500.00, to assist in the upkeep of the school on the understanding that Indian children would be admitted there being no Indian school in the Agency.

Mr Pollock before accepting the appointment, met the retiring master Mr Mc Garragle and was informed by him that the Department had increased the Grant and were now paying $750.00.

On the arrival of the first winter mail from Atlin on the 17th instant Mr Pollock received a Cheque, #2410, for $47.50, (The September stipend) and asked for an explanation. I informed him that I had not been notified of an increase on the original grant, and owing to the fact that Cheques for this service had been paid direct to recipient in late years I was unable to refute this statement, however I showed him that the Estimates called for $500.00, to cover salary, for the past and present Fiscal years. He will possibly communicate with you on this subject.

I have been appointed as teacher for the white children in the Provincial Government school at Telegraph Creek and now beg to make application for the position of teacher of the Indian children at this school, which I believe is one for the joint education of both whites and Indians.

I have already made application to Mr. W. Scott Simpson, the Indian agent, but understand he is now on his way to Atlin and other interior points and will not return for some time.

There has been a long standing controversy between the representatives of the Roman Catholic and Protestant Anglican Churches, respectively, as to which church merits an ascendancy in regard to residential school facilities as a result of the advent from time to time of their respective Missionaries. In response to my request, Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., of the R.C. Church and Reverend Commander Hodgson, Anglican Minister agreed to meet together at the Indian Office with the Agent and myself with a view to going over the Agency census and determining what Indians were reputed to belong to either of these churches, in other words to determine who are considered to be Roman Catholics and who are deemed to be of the Protestant faith. This action was thought necessary as a preliminary step in the direction of deciding what recommendation should be made to the Department with respect to Indian education in this large district; a residential school having been asked for during my visit by the Reverend Father Allard, O.M.I., for the accommodation of 92 children stated by him to have been baptized into the Roman Catholic Church. A list of these children was submitted by Father Allard.

Reverend Commander Hodgson of the Anglican Church had also submitted a list of families which embraced many of the children in the R.C. list.

A frank and fair discussion of the matter went to show that Indians baptized many years ago by the Anglicans had been rebaptized later with their children into the Roman Catholic Church and vice versa.

The Agency official census book was examined, Family by Family, and agreement was reached between the two Church representatives in regard to each subject, of course, to the acceptance of such status by the respective Family heads.

A distressful aspect was the division, through baptism, by the respective clergy, of families. In some cases, the fathers would be pagan, the mothers Catholic and the children Protestant. In other cases the father is Protestant, the mother Catholic, part of the children of one Church and part of another. Many old Indians were baptized by the Anglicans years ago and had lapsed into paganism, some of whom were now claimed by both Catholics and Protestants.

A decision was reached as to the status of
Extract from Asst. Commissioner Perry's Report (continued)

the Indians as understood by the clergymen. A subsequent numerical checkup shows as follows:

In the vicinity of Telegraph Creek, Tahltan and Dease Lake, including Bear Lake migrant visitors, there are,

Roman Catholics 120.
Anglican 150.

In the McDames and Liard districts there are claimed by the Roman Catholic clergyman 320 Indians, one-third of these are said to be nomads and are not claimed by the Anglicans. The Roman Catholic Church therefore expects to register these 320 Indians as Roman Catholics.

In the Atlin and Teslin districts at least two-thirds of the Indians, who in total number 222, are adherents of the Anglican Church. It was admitted that the work of the Anglican Church is increasing there while that of the Roman Catholic Church under Rev. Father Allard, O.M.I., is not extensive. Rev. Father Allard, O.M.I., stated that his Church would be willing to give up any missionary activities that might be prejudicial to the Anglican interests there, especially if the Department would be willing to make provision for a residential school for say 50 of 92 Catholic children of school age at a place called Six-Mile point which is on the right bank of Stikine River about 6 miles below Telegraph Creek. On the other hand, Rev. Commander Hodgson, of the Anglican Church, at Telegraph Creek, has suggested that if the Roman Catholic Church would be willing to vacate their Telegraph Creek Mission (where Rev. Father Allard has recently erected a church for the Indians in what the Anglicans believe to be their territory) the Anglicans might give up any claim they may have to missionary territory around McDames Creek and Dease Lake where however the Anglicans have no established or organized Missions. The Anglicans may offer some objection to the establishment of a residential school for the Roman Catholic Church near Telegraph Creek as they consider the district an Anglican missionary territory even though there is some lack of appreciable Missionary activity along educational lines on the part of the Anglicans in this district, the latter through Rev. Commander Hodgson claiming not to have any funds for such purpose. It should be pointed out that despite the past religious work of the Anglicans at Tahltan (now abandoned) and Telegraph Creek, the Roman Catholic Indians have erected new churches at Telegraph Creek and at McDames whether the Anglicans like it or not and the priest has decided to press for the education of the Indians who identify themselves with the Roman Catholic Faith and hence is asking that a departmental residential school be established under the supervision of the Catholic Church for Catholic children within the territory for which they have established these churches.

The Department will be aware of a medical
Extract from Asst. Commissioner Perry's report (cont'd.)

survey made in 1928 by Dr. Wride of the Indians in Stikine Agency, in view of which I pointed out to the clergyman concerned that a medical report of the present resident medical officer Dr. Edgellow as to the physical fitness of the 92 R.C. children to enter a residential school would appear to be necessary before consideration could be given to the request for a residential school. This suggestion met with approval, and Dr. Edgellow has promised to make a careful medical examination of the children whose names appear on the list of Rev. Father E. Allard, O.M.I.

Should a medical report on these children prove satisfactory, it would then be desirable that the Department give consideration to the question as to:

1. A residential school should be provided.
2. Whether such school should be denominational, undenominational or inter-denominational.
3. Whether or not the Anglicans' view that the Catholics are usurping their recognized Missionary territory or sphere of influence should be endorsed in view of the limited nature of the present Missionary work of the Anglicans and the recent more active work of the Roman Catholics in this district.

It seems to me that it might be reasonably deduced from the foregoing observation that as the Roman Catholic Church claims adherents numbering 440 and the Anglicans 372 (total population of Stikine Agency is 812) there would appear to be reasonable grounds on the part of the former to ask for separate educational facilities for at least 50 of their 92 children, particularly as the Anglicans have a residential school at Carcross, Y.T., which is near the center of their larger church activities and which has at present some accommodation and which might be extended if necessary in order to accommodate the Anglican children who might in future be found available for admission thereto. It is thought that an extension of educational facilities for the Anglican Church at Carcross by the Department for the accommodation of Anglican children should fully compensate them for any obviously questionable loss they may claim to have sustained by the advent of the Catholics into their Missionary territory which at present is showing very slight signs of either religious or educational activity. The children of the district around Telegraph Creek are attending the Provincial public school, while the Mission at Tahltan is deserted and practically abandoned. Should the Department be inclined to recognize the claims of the Roman Catholics to a
residential school for Catholic children, it is recommended that such a school be established at 6-mile Point where acreage of sufficient area might be obtained from the Provincial Government which is understood to have placed a reserve on it for educational purposes. I have examined the site and believe the same to be quite suitable for this purpose. It is further recommended that a special inspection be made at the Carcross Indian Residential School which at present seems to bear an unsavoury reputation in the North, with a view of bringing it to a higher degree of efficiency and in order that the children of Anglican families in the Stikine Agency may be given suitable and satisfactory residential school accommodation and supervision. Of course, this recommendation is made subject to a satisfactory report being made by our medical officer respecting the physical fitness of the applicant pupils.

I should advise you that your suggestion to have a joint undenominational school for Stikine Agency while approved by Reverend Hodgson for the Anglicans, is not received with satisfaction by Reverend E. Allard, O.M.I., of the Catholic Church.

It should further be pointed out that the erection of a residential school at McDames, or Dease Lake for the Catholics as suggested by Rev. Hodgson would be fraught with great expense; while such a school if erected on the bank of the Stikine at a proper elevation would cost a great deal less as freight could be landed close to the proposed site. Moreover it is believed that the Stikine River will always be a main artery into the Cassiar country even though a public highway may be made into Dease Lake and Alaska from the south in the future. Moreover there is a beautiful creek and splendid fishing right at this proposed school site where fish food could easily be obtained for the use of the pupils.

Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of February 1939.

The first half of this month was occupied in giving the usual attention to various matters that arrive for action in and around the Head Office in Telegraph Creek. Nothing of serious account took place that needs special attention, but the old local school question did crop up once more when it was discovered that out of 16 Indian youngsters attending - 12 of them really needed prompt attention given to their tonsils.

On a special request from the Minister of Health for the Province, which no doubt was sent out to all Provincial Schools the local Doctor 'n every area received instructions to carry out a special inspection, not only of the children but also of the buildings and all connections. Therefore, this was done by Dr. Meyer, M.D. and looking through the Indian Office files on this matter he saw at a glance that no action has been received for many years in regard to our local school and its decent teaching conditions. Therefore a rather drastic report was rendered, which rather shocked our local Government Agent, but which it is hoped by all the people in Telegraph Creek will result in some action by the Province to improve matters generally. The school building was condemned years ago, and since that time the youngsters 'n the Town have greatly increased, so that today it is a matter of overcrowding. This is rather serious in a community where T.B. is known to exist, and the home conditions of the various half-breeds and Indians are not anywhere up to a standard of decent living. The whole matter is the subject of a Report to the Indian Commissioner in Vancouver, B.C. and no doubt now the Province has started to mend conditions, our remote locality will eventually come up for some attention. We have no Revenue in the Cassiar at present and the Tax Payers are today unable to carry the expenses of an entirely new school building - many of which are half-breed families, living in the Townsite, and sometimes on relief.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.
Sir:

I beg to submit hereunder a report covering the month of January 1939.

A matter that came up for attention this month was that of the local Telegraph Creek Provincial Day School and its overcrowding, with the question who should, and who should not decide as to what Indians might attend.

This school building is very ancient, and has been already condemned, but as we are so remote from Victoria Headquarters, and take with the fact that practically no Provincial Revenue is taken out of the District, little attention is given or for that matter - can be expected, in regard to a new school building - from the Provincial Authorities "below". The number of children in this community is out of all proportion to the size of its townsite, and this means much overcrowding in regards to their home living quarters. In fact to state the matter briefly, the unsanitary conditions of Telegraph Creek are well known to the Provincial Authorities in Victoria, and is the subject of ridicule in Wrangel, S.E. Alaska which is at the mouth of the Stikine River. Over many years efforts have been made to clear matters up, and all doctors here have during their residence tried to have matters adjusted, but have met with no help whatsoever.

It now comes to light that matters in regard to Provincial Schools have not been reported upon as they should have been, which resulted in a Circular Letter from the B.C. Authorities, requesting a more detailed reports from the resident doctors concerned. Dr. Hey's copy arrived just at the time the overcrowding was under review at this point, and he has turned in a very urgent, if drastic report on the whole matter. There are at present 43 children attending this school, 16 of whom are Indians, 3 of which are white children, the rest being half-breeds. Their air space is 118 cubic feet per child, which is not enough especially as most of these children are not clean, wear skin shoes and live in very bad home surroundings. Out of the 16 Indian children 12 have to receive tonsil medical attention, and this is urgent, and the other children are in no better shape.

As far generally is vanishing the outside Indian families in the near district wish to come into town, send their children to this school, and as they cannot support their families apply for relief, and practically live on store provisions. If these families can send their children to other schools, and have even promised to do so, i.e., to the Thalton reserve summer school and the Klappan winter school, an effort was made to restrict their coming into town, with the excuse of using this local school.
It certainly is considered that had this agency a Constable attached to this office, all this could have been prevented but a Provincial Constable, even if he would, could not be asked to stop Indian children attending a Provincial School, which might receive some assistance if it were shown that overcrowding existed.

Some "ruling" is really needed, for there are other large Indian families herabouts that even now think they have a right to come into this small Townsite for the winters - go without their natural food of meat and fish etc., and with relief send their children to the local Provincial school. Only an Indian Agent, with the help of the resident doctor, should be allowed to pass on such matters in a nomadic Indian district.

It is also pointed out, which is not necessary, that if this is allowed to continue, the other schools will be depleted of children and will therefore have to close down.

The matter has been reported upon at length, as it has been coming to a head over the last two or three years.

The relief question has not advanced to any extent over the month, and with the arrival of June 1st, all relief will be reduced over the coming summer time.

I am,

Sir,

Your obedient servant,

On the evening of the 20th inst. the affairs of the Telegraph Creek Provincial Day school came up for public attention, by the residents, or tax payers of the town. It had been impossible to obtain sufficient number of Tax Payers in the spring time, so therefore the annual Meeting had been deferred until now. During the last 2 years or more, all affairs of the school had been handled by the local Government Agent, in conjunction with the school's Principal; but more so at the hands of the latter. Due to local conditions etc., matters had arrived in a very bad state as at the Mid-winter term of a year ago; and therefore, to safeguard the Indian children attending, the matter was taken up by this office with the help of the local doctor, Dr. G.W. Meyer, M.D., C.M., now in residence here does not only attend to the requirements of the Indians; but also in the Provincial Medical of Health. Matters were placed in front of him, by this office in a very drastic manner; resulting from complaints laid by the parents of Indian children attending this school. Affairs were found to be in a shocking condition; which eventually resulted in this school house being condemned, as it was. Sanitary matters have since improved, but otherwise matters are to-day as they were.

At this meeting the Govt. Agent resigned as "in charge" of Provincial matters, and a Board of Trustees created. No explanation was given as to why conditions were as they were, nor any information allowed for future improvement. After the meeting, affairs were in the hands of the Tax-Payers, and speaking as at this date, the school is running along - as ever it did.

The school premises etc. is really no concern of this office except in the case of overcrowding & health matters, and should more Indians live within this Townsite over next winter, overcrowding will be in excess of anything yet achieved- which fact does concern the Indian Office. However, here again, is a very important matter that should receive the consideration of the agency's Inspector upon his visit to these parts during the coming summer, and some very definite rules should be created so that the matter of attendance comes entirely under the authority of the Indian Office; and would not be for the consideration for such local Provincial Authorities as there happens to be. This whole matter has already been reported upon several times; and therefore the following references are given. Ottawa. 150-43-1933. Report to Indian Commissioner, Vancouver, dated November 17th.

AGENT'S REPORT ON STIKINE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JUNE 1941.

On the 21st inst. Bishop Coudret O.M.I., of the R.C. Missions arrived for his yearly inspection of the Cassiar. All matters were again gone over with him, and the various Seasonal schools were taken in hand and teachers and supplies arranged for. Later these were reported upon, but it is doubtful just at present if it will be possible to have a teacher go out to the Caribou Hide school. However the Department have been good enough to allow the sum of One hundred dollars towards getting the much needed freight out to that point, and the matter is now receiving attention as to the possibility of engaging a plane for such work. During the interview, some mention was made that a lot of local children were living within the Township during the winter, and did not attend the local Provincial school, and that if the local R.C. Mission could start up a small winter school at this point, many children would certainly attend. It was at once pointed out that should this be entertained matters in the Township would certainly become worse than they are at present; and the object of our Bush Winter schools would be entirely nullified. Eventually His Lordship agreed that such was the case, and it is hoped the matter is settled again, for some time to come. Telegraph Creek is certainly no place for an Indian winter school.

Harper Reed,
Indian agent.
Stikine, Telegraph Creek, B.C.

Sir,

The building has been condemned as unfit for present usage, but as the district is poverty-stricken, and the Provincial Authorities cannot see their way clear as yet to build a new School-house, it has to be retained in operation for a time yet. REPORT ON STIKINE AGENCY FOR MONTH OF JULY.

On the 13th inst the yearly school board meeting was held, or was to be held, for the local Provincial Day school, but so few local persons took an interest in this affair, that it was impossible to call the meeting to order. The situation in this Townsite is extreme. Most of the children attending this school are halfbreeds, or straight Indians; and therefore the parents cannot take a lively interest. Moreover these half-breeds are living from hand to mouth, even more so than our Indians, whilst many do not live in the Townsite and so do not pay taxes etc. This is certainly one place in British Columbia at which the Provincial School authorities should take the whole matter upon themselves and supply the necessary housing and equipment to carry on their Provincial School education. This community simply cannot shoulder the expenses now necessary to place this school in a sanitary and well running condition. However a report on this school was submitted to the department, pointing out the difficulties encountered in making all our Indian children attend this school regularly, during the winter times when they reside within the townsite.

Harper Reed,
Indian Agent.
Telegraph Creek, Provincial Day School.

About a dozen Indians bought lots in the Town of Telegraph Creek and those with children have been taking advantage of the Provincial Public School, there being three children in attendance at the present time, all Anglicans, for whom the usual grant is paid by the province, also two others living in Telegraph Creek not entitled to the grant.

The children usually in attendance are given by the Teacher as follows:

  - Joseph Nehass - Age 6

- Telegraph Creek:
  - Doris Brooks - Age 15

The present teacher, Mr. J.W. Hughes, an ordained Anglican is considered by Mr. Inspector Barry to be very competent.

I visited the school on September 30th and find that it consists of a log building 30' x 28' x 8'6 inside walls, with teacher's residence above. It is in very poor condition. There are three windows in each side of the class room, loose for want of caulking around the frames, while the inside of the room is lined with metal sheeting; these conditions make it very draughty and in the very low sub-zero winter temperatures the single box stove is quite inefficient. All the 115 cubic feet air space per pupil in inadequate, likewise the window lighting. The only ventilation is from the wall and window leakages. The roof of the building is corrugated iron and leaks in several places.

Five fires have occurred in the building in recent years. Sanitation consists of two dilapidated latrines. Due to general conditions of the building colds among the pupils are very prevalent, with the usual lowering of resistance of the Indian pupils to pulmonary affections.

Desk accommodation consists of 39 good single desks and 5 old double desks for an average attendance of about 40 pupils but a considerable increase during the winter months.

The Provincial Government and School Trustees are most anxious to close the school to Indians for the reason that it is not able to accommodate all the local white children, but feel that they are unable to do so legally.

Suggested Indian School.

The situation existing here of a number of Indians living in a Provincial town, hardly any of which offers a decent building
site and only partly supplied with domestic water for half the year, entirely without sanitation, is bound to give rise to strong criticism. The Indians are discouraged from improving their homes as it results in an increase of taxes. Conditions are particularly wretched on the section known as "Dry Town" which is without water, except when obtained by clambering up and down an almost sheer rock cliff, probably 200' high, to the Stikine River, which is very muddy. Adjoining the townsite is the Cassco Reserve, a high bench, obtaining far more sunlight in the winter than the town and having excellent possibilities for a well-located domestic water system at a very low cost. The reason that it has not been settled on is undoubtedly due to Mr. Reid's arbitrary refusal to permit Indians to build homes in the vicinity of the town, with the mistaken idea that it would drive them out into the bush in the winter. If they were all trappers with traplines there might have been some reason for this attitude, but even then it is not the wish of every Indian to take his wife and young children out on the trail and often this is not possible or desirable for medical reasons.

The solution to the problem is to build a school on the Reserve, complete with teacher's residence. This would undoubtedly result in the Indians leaving the townsite, particularly if domestic water were made available (vide report on Cassco Reserve). In addition to the advantages of our own educational system for Indians and many more children being educated, I would expect a considerable improvement in health and eventual reduction of necessity of relief and medical attention.

The present set up is that we have 35 children, 9 being of school age and 16 under age, all Anglicans, on the Cassco Reserve; 18 of school age and 13 under age, resident in Telegraph Creek Townsite, all Anglicans; and 33 of school age and 35 under age, resident in the summer months on the Reserve on the Stikine River opposite the Townsite. This sums up as 37 Anglicans of school age, now resident practically all the year round and 32 Catholics during the summer.

It would be practically impossible to get both an Anglican and a Catholic teacher to teach for half a year each, owing to the difficulty of access to the Agency and the high cost of living. I would suggest that the difficulty could be overcome by employing an undenominational teacher for the full year, holding school for the Anglicans from November 1st to April 30th (6 months) and for the Catholics from May 15th to October 31st (5½ months). The Catholics are all from the Klappan area and this proposal would make the present winter school there unnecessary. The respective missionaries could be given full access during their respective periods, for reasonable religious instruction.

Such a school should provide accommodation for forty pupils as the attendance is likely to increase owing to the number of children now under school age. It should be provided with living quarters as there is no accommodation whatever in the townsite. Due to the high cost of living at this point, the salary should be at least $1000.00 per annum, preferably $1300.00. The absence of a qualified practitioner places us in a very serious position during the winter, Dr. Meyer now having resigned. Even if a doctor can be secured, which is doubtful, he is seriously handicapped in operative work without an assistant. This combination would offset any objections to the undenominational aspects of the school by either religious body.

Roughly, the cost of such a school, complete with furnace and furnishings, not including desks, is estimated at about $6,000, the walls being fabricated with plywood inside and put directly on to the studding and insulated to reduce fuel requirements, cost of which is about twice that elsewhere. It might be advisable to allow an extra $1,000 on the cost owing to freight; my first figure is based on the fact that it cost the Hudson's Bay Company about $6,000 to erect their residence four or five years ago, the construction being similar to that suggested. The school would not be very much larger. The Pemberton Indian Day School is an excellent layout for this type of school and residence.
The provision of a one-room day school with teacher's residence, as recommended by Mr. Coleman, would appear to be necessary to meet requirements at Telegraph Creek. This project should be given consideration as soon as funds can be provided.
