Dear Mr. Neary:

I am in receipt of your communication re the Seasonal Schools of the Stikine Agency.

1.-Shesley School.-In order to comply with the urgent request of Agent Simpson two years ago, we opened with much difficulty the School at Shesley. As I told you in previous correspondence, our last year experience at that point was indeed very hard and almost disheartening; but our missionaries realized that it was only beginning, and they were fully decided to make of it a success. In view of that, I sent three priests to Telegraph Creek last summer with the intention of getting the Shesley School going properly. As you will know, our plans were all upset last Fall, just as our missionaries were getting ready to start out for Shesley, and the Indian Agent requested permission to open a School at Telegraph Creek.

As a matter of fact, the Indians having now returned to Shesley, after New Year's, our fathers decided to go there; they are now at Shesley, and as communications are almost impossible with that point except through special charter of airplane or dogteam, we shall not know the results of this second attempt until they come back in the spring.

By that time, the Branch will be in a better position to take a final decision concerning the future of said school. I think that it was only fair both to the Indians concerned and to our missionaries to make this second attempt, after all the expenses already incurred, before deciding to close such a school.

2.-Klappan School at Telegraph Creek.-In regard to the School opened last Fall in Telegraph Creek, also at the urgent request of the Agent, I was surprised at your unfavorable report. Father Forget, the teacher, appeared to have been quite pleased with the results so far, and he stated in his last correspondence that he had 35 Catholic Indian Children around Telegraph Creek who were benefitting by said school.

Of course, if you would know the local conditions in Telegraph Creek, you could not expect the attendance to be as good as in remotest places, where the Indian families live around the school and have no distraction of any kind.-The village of Telegraph Creek is located at the bottom of a canyon, with dwellings scattered in an area of several miles extending as far as the summits of the surrounding hills; with the icy condition of the trails and the darkness prevailing in winter time, many children are bound to miss the morning period. Moreover the many local amusements and other attractions detaining the parents and preventing them from...
VICARIATE APOSTOLIC OF WHITEHORSE

going to bed until late at night do not favor evidently the early rising of the children.

Notwithstanding all that, owing to the expenses we have gone through in transforming our little local church into a school, I advised Father Forget to continue on teaching at Telegraph Creek this winter as long as he would have a reasonable amount of children in attendance.

The Kluane school being closed for lack of Indians at that place is another reason why I advised to keep the Telegraph Creek school opened.

In a few weeks I am going to fly into Telegraph Creek, and will by that time be in a better position to report more accurately on the whole situation. I expect to be there until the latter part of March.

Owing to the difficulties of communication with Telegraph Creek, I doubt whether all the children of school age will be able to be recruited for the Teslin School from that area, outside of the orphans and destitute children unless they are brought in Teslin by special chartered plane every summer and fall. Plane communications are indeed the only normal communications with that part of our Vicariate Apostolic. Even if they are sent by boat via Wrangell in Alaska, they will not be able to travel by boat from Wrangell to Skagway—the only passenger boats in that part of the Alaskan panhandle being Canadian steamers, which are forbidden to carry passengers from an American port to an American port. When our missionaries travel this way, they have to fly from Wrangell to Skagway, and then take the train from Skagway to Whitehorse. The only direct communication from Telegraph Creek to Teslin is, therefore, by air, and everything considered, it is the shortest and cheapest way.

This communication problem between Telegraph Creek and Teslin will have to be thoroughly studied and settled by the Officials of the Branch when the Boarding School at Teslin is in operation next year.

Hoping that the above information will prove useful to you and the other Officials of the Branch to enable you to understand the unique situation of that part of the country, I assure you once more of my earnest desire fully to cooperate with the Branch for the welfare of the natives of our Apostolic Vicariate.

Yours sincerely in Christ,

Dear Mr.Phelan:

I am sending you herewith the accounts for the Renting of our various School Buildings to the Branch during the Calendar Year 1948.

For the renting of our building in Telegraph Creek for the School Term of 1947-1948 in favor of the Klappan Band, if you remember well, we were unable to have the Klappan Indians go to their hunting grounds in Klappan owing to prevailing diseases; at the request of the local Agent (later on approved by the Officials of the Branch) a temporary school was set up in our own buildings in Telegraph Creek in November 1947; for that purpose we had to make quite a few rather expensive alterations. The school only lasted three months, and had to be discontinued on account of the Indians returning to their various hunting grounds during the course of the winter.

To my knowledge, so far as our books are concerned, no rent was as yet collected for the use of our buildings during those three months in Telegraph Creek, B.C. (Stikine Agency).

As to this winter, our fathers have prevailed upon the Indians to return early to their hunting ground of Klappan, and they accompanied them in the first week of November, so as to be able to teach steadily until next April; they should be able to put in five or six months of schooling at Klappan; I have already included the two months of November and December, wherein the school has been already opened.

N.B.-Father Forget, at the date of Dec.10, complains that he has not yet received the Refund I applied for, when I visited you in Ottawa last October.

Fathers Morisset and Drea have not yet received their cheques for their schooling of last summer; I advised them to write to you directly, when sending their Forms T.D.1a for 1949.

Kindly have the cheques for the School Rent made out directly to "The Catholic Episcopal Corporation of Whitehorse", so that in my absence to Europe, the Secretary of our Corporation may endorse them and put them in our account; right now, our Corporation is in an urgent need of that money to pay the bills of our new Residence here in Whitehorse. I hope, therefore, that there will not be too much delay in the settlement of those accounts.

Thanking you again for your kindness, and wishing you a most Happy and successful Year in all your undertakings, I remain, Dear Mr.Phelan,

W.S. Arneil, Esq., Indian Comm'r. for B.C., Vancouver.

In a recent interview with the Telegraph Creek School Board, which operates a two-room elementary school here, the suggestion was made that a combined school for white and Indian children might be operated here to advantage. The Board agreed to take the matter up with the Provincial Education Department to see if they approved of such a step.

The request for the School Board's opinion on this subject was motivated by the need for providing schooling for some twenty-five to thirty Indian children living in the vicinity of Telegraph Creek. This number is in addition to fifteen Indian children whose parents are tax-payers and who are therefore entitled to attend the provincial school.

The Province made an attempt to build a school here last year, but through shortage of materials were unable to go through with the project. They realized that the small, unsuitable school here was inadequate to properly take care of the growing needs in the locality. Both class-rooms are presently crowded, and one of the rooms is entirely unsuitable for the purpose. It is therefore going to be necessary to provide increased space for the ever-growing attendance list, or deny schooling to some of the children. Obviously the Indian children will be the first to suffer.

As it appears the Department is not contemplating establishing an Indian day school here, it is felt they might consider constructing and operating a combined white and Indian school with the Province. If there is any possibility of such a step it is respectfully suggested that the Superintendent of Education at Victoria be contacted directly as the local School Board is placing the matter in his hands for consideration.

R.H.S. Sampson, Indian Supt.

Dear Sir:

As instructed by you, I visited Telegraph Creek to investigate the question of school accommodation at that point. I arrived in Telegraph Creek on the evening of June 22 and remained there until the evening of the twenty-third. As a result of my inspection of the school, followed by a very complete survey of the town-site, an investigation of the probable attendance figures for the next five years, and a meeting with the local School Board, I wish to submit the following report.

Present School Accommodation.

The school enrolment in September 1948 was 79 with 77 pupils attending fairly regularly throughout the year. At the time of my visit 71 pupils' names were being carried on the school roll. The variation in school attendance figures is due to the migratory nature of some of the Indian families.

Two teachers are employed by the board neither of whom have had any teacher training. The work of the grade one teacher is quite commendable. I was not satisfied with the work being accomplished by the teacher of the senior room.

The school accommodation available is appalling to the degree that it is beyond description. Forty-nine pupils are enrolled in the senior room which occupies the class room space on the ground floor. The dimensions of this class room are 20 ft. by 31 ft. with considerable space taken up in the centre of the room by a chimney and barrel type heater. Pupils are seated in double and triple desks. Lighting is totally inadequate.

The attic of the school which was formerly used as a teacher's residence is now used to house the grade one pupils who range in age from 6 to 12 years. Access to this room is secured by means of a very steep stairs attached to the rear of the school. The dimensions of this room are 12 ft. by 31 ft. with a ceiling height varying from 5 ft. 6 in. at the sides to 7 ft. 8 in. at the centre. The chimney and barrel type heater located in the centre of the room occupy a great part of the floor space. TWENTY-TWO youngsters are taught in this room. Conditions of sanitation and of fire hazard are unbelievable.

Two ancient and small privies are available to the school. No washing facilities are available. During summer the children may drink from a small stream of water at the rear of the school.
The school grounds measure 100 ft. by 120 ft. with about two-thirds of the area available for the school building and playground. The remainder is extremely steep hillside.

**Estimate of Probable School Attendance.**

The following probable school attendance figures for the future are based upon information supplied by the teachers as a result of a careful analysis of the population figures for the district made in conjunction with the Indian Agent, Mr. Sampson.

**Pre-school age children - White.**

There are 19 children in this category but their ages were not available without more investigation than time permitted.

It is difficult to forecast the length of time that the Indian children will remain at school. Estimating the retaining power of the school at a reasonably low rate it is concluded that THREE classrooms will be required for September 1949 and that allowance should be made for a probable extension to four class rooms in 1951 or 1952.

**School Building Program Recommended.**

I would recommend that a three room school be constructed immediately with provision made in the planning for a possible addition of a fourth class room. I am aware that this recommendation raises very considerable problems of (a) suitable site (b) type and method of construction (c) financing. Under these headings I would report as follows:
(a) Site.

This is a most difficult problem. The town-site of Telegraph Creek rises abruptly from the river in a series of small benches. Every conceivable method of locating a building on the present site was investigated. It is impossible to find room for three class rooms on the present site.

Considerable time was spent in covering every available piece of reasonably level ground in the area. I am convinced that there is no satisfactory solution to this problem. Three alternative proposals were suggested to the School Board. The Board unanimously settled on a site immediately above the present school. I am satisfied that this decision is the best that can be made.

(b) Type and method of Construction.

Under conditions of material supply existing at Telegraph Creek I am convinced that the best type of construction can be secured by using squared timbers. Framing lumber, shiplap, etc., can be cut locally. The owner of the local mill was interviewed and he stated that he would be unable to cut any lumber before August. Cutting should be started immediately. The Public Works own a mill and arrangements might be made to have the work done by the Public Works Department.

I would recommend the following steps be taken:

1. A plan be drawn for a three room school capable of expansion to four rooms. Plumbing cannot be provided but storage facilities for water for drinking and for some fire protection should be included.

2. A capable carpenter-foreman should be employed to go to Telegraph Creek to supervise the building project.

3. The Public Works should be asked to co-operate:
   (a) To level the grounds.
   (b) To use their mill to cut the squared timber, dimension, etc.

4. Arrangements should be made to send in material not available in Telegraph Creek.

I am aware that this section of the report is very sketchy. I am prepared to offer more detail regarding construction problems if it is decided to go ahead with this project.

(c) Financing.

Based upon information secured regarding the cost of building the Police Barracks and the Indian Department's Office building I would estimate the cost of building a suitable school might approach $100,000.

At the present time there are 25 wards of the Indian Department.
attending school. During the next five years 79 children will enter school of which number 50 will be wards of the Indian Department. It was suggested to me that the number of Indian children might increase when regular and adequate school facilities were available but I have no facts to support this suggestion.

The figures quoted above would indicate that the Indian Department should be involved in the financing of any school construction undertaken.

In addition to the problem of school accommodation three other matters were discussed with the Board. These were:

1. Teaching Staff.
   This school is not receiving good instruction. I suggested the following measures to the Board.
   (a) That they pay a Northern Living Allowance of at least six hundred dollars per annum.
   (b) That the present school be used as a teachers residence.
   (c) That they avail themselves of the offer of Mr. Malziel to fly the teachers from Watson Lake to Telegraph Creek free of charge.

2. Indian Department representation of the School Board.
   The School Board asked me to transmit to the Department their suggestion that the resident Indian Agent should automatically become a member of the School Board.

3. Payment of a Secretary-Treasurer.
   The Board wishes to have authority to hire a Secretary-Treasurer at a salary of $30 per month.

This report has been prepared in the minimum of time. I returned from Telegraph Creek to my home only the day before I had to leave for the Coast. I am submitting the report immediately upon my arrival because of the necessity for an early decision upon the course of action to be taken to meet the situation existing at Telegraph Creek.

Yours very truly,

S.J. Graham,
Inspector of Schools.

MEMORANDUM

Re: Telegraph Creek Joint School

Following instructions given by Mr. Neary in his letter of July 4th, I approached the Department of Education regarding the establishment of a joint school at Telegraph Creek on July 15th. I attended a meeting with the Deputy Minister of Education and his Executive Assistant. A second meeting, attended by Mr. Superintendent Sampson and myself was held on July 22nd with the Executive Assistant and the Provincial Inspector, Mr. S.J. Graham, who had visited Telegraph Creek with the purpose of inspecting the existing Provincial school and of reporting on the present accommodation and requirements. A copy of his report has been made available to me and I attach it herewith. I shall comment fully on this report at the end of my memorandum, but one point to be noted now is that Mr. Graham has included all Indian children in his figures and has not separated Protestant and Catholic groups. As you are aware, it is the policy of the Provincial Department to admit children to their schools without consideration of "race, colour or creed", and its schools operate on non-denominational lines. For a number of years Indian children of both denominations have been attending the
Provincial school at Telegraph Creek. Now apparently because a new building is to be constructed, a segregation is to take place which will deny the right of attendance of the Catholic group of this Band, which is doubly unfortunate in that it will also segregate part of the Indian population from the white group. This is because the Indian Affairs Branch will not assume the responsibility for the cost of educating the Catholic children in this Provincial school, although it does do so at other points. The reason for this is apparently that at some later date there is likely to be a request for the construction of a separate school for the Catholic children. It will be noted from the attached projection of the school population that the number of white and Protestant Indian children will require a three room school, which can also accommodate the additional number of Catholic children until 1952, when an additional room will be required because of the increase in the Indian population. This addition would have to be financed by our Department. If however the Catholic children were permitted to attend until 1952 and segregated then, the Provincial three room school would be adequate for another five or six years. Since there is little likelihood that our Department will be able to provide separate accommodation for
two or three years it seems that the Indian Affairs Branch should make possible the admission of Catholic children to the Provincial school until such time as it is necessary and possible to provide separate accommodation. Since the Catholic and Protestant Indian children have been attending in past years there does not appear to be any very good reason why such a separation would be any more difficult at that time than at the present. It will be noted that the increase in the school age population is due almost entirely to the increase in the number of Indian children, nor is there any likelihood that this will be changed by enfranchisements as in the past eight years there have been only two or three in the whole of the Stikine Agency. The total school age population represents 55% of the possible enrolment but if the Catholic children are omitted the Indian enrolment will be 44%. It will be noted that the Catholic Indian population is increasing more rapidly than the Protestant group and will in a few years form about one-third of the school population.

It will be noted from Mr. Inspector Graham's report that his estimate of the school attendance for September 1949 is six higher than my own. This is due to Mr. Graham adopting a more optimistic view of the possible attendance of a family of Indians living at some distance from Telegraph Creek. This
point was discussed with the Provincial authorities who are prepared to accept my figures, which were prepared from lists submitted by Mr. Superintendent Sampson and were considered with Mr. Graham on the occasion of our meeting on July 22nd.

Site:

It will be noted that the Provincial Board has selected a site which they consider most suitable. I might add that I know the location and visited it in June 1948. Both Mr. Sampson and myself are in agreement that this is not only the best possible choice for the white population but is also the most convenient location for serving our Indian population.

Type and Method of Construction:

At our meeting on July 22nd it was decided that the method outlined by Mr. Graham was most suitable. It was decided however that excavation would be made only for the installation of the heating plant. This will reduce the estimated cost of the building.

Cost:

It is not possible to give an accurate estimate of the cost at the present time. However the Provincial authorities expect to be able to give a fairly accurate figure in about two weeks time. It was felt at the meeting with the Provincial authorities that Mr. Graham's estimate of the cost of the building at $100,000 was extremely high in view of the
type of construction and the cost of our new Agency building at this point. It will be possible however to check this against the estimate of the architect when the plans are completed.

Summary:

I recommend that our Department make provision for the admission of both denominations of the Indian population in the new Provincial school and if necessary provide a separate school for the Catholic population in about three years time when we would undoubtedly be approached by the Province to bear the cost of an addition made necessary by the increase in the Indian population. This will mean that the Indian Affairs Branch would bear 55% of the cost of construction.

The Province hopes to begin construction within the next month and for this reason an early reply is required as to whether the Department is agreeable to this basis for an agreement.

R.F. Davey,
District Inspector of Indian Schools in B.C.
Indian Affairs Branch,
Dept. Mines and Resources,
Ottawa, Ontario.

Re: Telegraph Creek School.

With reference to Mr. Neary's letter of May 25, I am forwarding a self-explanatory memorandum from District School Inspector Davey with the enclosures referred to therein. You will note that the Province intends to commence construction of a 3-room school at Telegraph Creek in about a month's time, and that this building will provide adequate accommodation for the white pupils and the Indian pupils, both Protestant and Catholic, and that the three rooms will probably be adequate for another five or six years.

Since the Catholic and Protestant Indian children have been attending the same schools for the past years, there would appear to be no reason why the arrangement should not be continued on the understanding that in a few years time, when the available pupilage necessitates additional accommodation, a separate school will be provided for Catholic Indian pupils.

With regard to the cost of the Provincial School building, there can be no doubt that Inspector Graham's estimate is out of all reason, having in mind the type of construction proposed and the cost of the modern framebuilding erected by this department last year for use as an office and clerk's quarters. It is hoped that a definite figure covering cost of the building will be available in a few weeks so that the department's share—based on 55% of the enrollment if the Catholic children are included, or 44% if they are excluded—may be calculated.
In closing, I might mention that it was not until this matter was discussed with Mr. Sampson that we realized that Indian children of both religious denominations had been attending the Provincial School for some years, and further that the operation of the proposed 3-room Provincial School is not expected to effect attendance at the Klappan seasonal school.

Dear Mr. Davey:

I received a telegram today from Mr. Marr, our Building Supervisor, who is in Telegraph Creek and our closest estimate of the cost of the proposed building and equipment is $50,169. However, the labour situation is not entirely firm and if it became necessary to use Vancouver labour, the cost would be somewhat higher. To be on the safe side, I would suggest that we allow $65,000 for the project and if there is any saving, that would be all to the good.

As you know, this amount is considerably less than the preliminary estimate that was made in my office several weeks ago.

Naturally, we would prefer to have the Indian Affairs Branch assume 55% of the cost but I understand very well that this will depend upon the decision which will be made from Ottawa.

If anything can be done to expedite the approval of your Government's share of the total cost, it will be much appreciated.

Yours very truly,

Sir,

Re:- Telegraph Creek Provincial Day School,
December Report.

I beg to submit herewith the above report covering
the quarter ending December 31st 1940.

At the end of December there were 14 children in
attendance at this school. Most of these were from
Homes within the Townsite, and which parents were
paying the Town School Tax, and therefore do not
show on the submitted Report. The four children
marked in red (R) do reside on the near by Casca
Reserve, and were passed as correct to appear on
this School Report.

The 4 Etzerza Children came to Town this Fall and
reside just outside the Town's Limits, but not on
the Indian Reserve. Therefore they do not pay the
local school taxes, and so the Schoolmaster has placed
them on his Report, with the hope that they will be
allowed to pass as Reserve Children.

The above facts are submitted for the Departments con-
sideration, but if payment is allowed for children
of Indian families who will not live on the Reserve,
then any indian family could come to Town for the
winter, send their youngsters to school, and live
off the Reserve. This of course, it is considered,
would lead to much trouble.

I am, Sir,

The Secretary
Indian Affairs Branch
Dept Mines & Resources
OTTAWA.

Your obedient servant.

Harper Reed
Indian Agent.

Sir:

I have your letter of the 25th ultimo, addressed to Mr. Sutherland of this Department, regarding the amount of salary which you received as teacher of the Telegraph Creek combined white and Indian school for the school years 1922-23 and 1923-24.

I find that for the school year 1922-23 (Sept. 1, 1922, to June 30, 1923) you were paid a total of $497.50, a deduction of $2.50 being made on account of the school having been open during the September quarter (1923) a period of only 19 days out of 20 teaching days. For the school year, September 1, 1923, to June 30, 1924, you were paid the full salary allowed, viz: $500.

As previously explained, the bonus was discontinued in the case of teachers in combined schools from the 1st of April, 1924, the beginning of the present fiscal year.

I am duty here at the usual time specified in the Manual of B.C. School Law and for your information quote from the Rules and Regulations, page 54, art. 2 clause 2 (a).

"In all schools throughout the Province the summer vacation shall cover the period between the last Friday in June and the Tuesday immediately following the first Monday in September". The first Monday in Sept. being Labor Day is, of course a legal holiday; there were 19 school days in that month of 1922 and School was held on each occasion. You will notice I was paid $47.50 for this month, a deduction, evidently, of $2.50 being made for some reason.

$47.50 + ($2.50) x 12 = $600.00

Again your attention is directed to the Dec. March and June quarters following at $150.00 per quarter.

$150.00 x 4 = $600.00.

And further as I happen to be rather a keen follower of Federal Affairs in general and political issues in particular I find that on consulting the Auditor-General's Report for 1922-23, part I, Indian Affairs Dept., sessional paper on Indian Education, page I-89, there is a statement of the salary paid me for 4 months to December 31, and the figures given are $147.50 and which tally exactly with my own. The same page also gives the bonus for 7 months to March 31, as $105.00 which is likewise correct. Therefore on the Department's own evidence...
It is very clear that for the school year 1922-23 I was paid at the rate of $600.00 per annum.

For the past two years at the rate of $600 p.a. I should have been paid up to the present a total of $1200.00 salary but only received $447.50 leaving a balance still due me of $202.50 plus the unpaid bonus.

I did not receive a number of letters regarding the forwarding of a duplicate copy of my Sept. (1913) Report supposed to have gone astray in the mail.

The first intimation of the report being missing came from Mr Scott Simpson, who rushed up to the schoolhouse to inform me of this and I immediately sat down and in his presence made out a duplicate as requested. That same afternoon on receiving my mail at the P.O. I found a letter from Mr Russell T. Ferrier containing a similar request but his letter was dated April 24 whereas Mr Scott Simpson's bore a date six days previous. Both letters were received by the same mail and the duplicate report was promptly sent off by the first available mail this probably reaching you about June 6, as stated in your letter; the second letter I had was dated June 5 and again asked for a duplicate report but as that had already gone forward I ignored this letter for that and other reasons. This missing report seems to be a mystery and it is almost impossible to conceive that in a well regulated office it should take over six months to
make the discovery whilst in the interval another quarterly report had been received and the salary paid; it appears to me that there has been gross laxity in some quarters. The bonus statement in this paragraph is paltry in its pecuniary and why should I be, in any case, the victim of the vagaries of the mail service.

Your final paragraph would appear to be a reflection on my powers of understanding but although I have been engaged in the scholastic profession for over 30 years I do not think that my faculties have yet become so impaired as to unfit me for doing a simple mental calculation in multiplication.

Before taking any further steps I shall await, with interest, your reply which ought to reach me about the third week in December (first winter mail).

I am,

Yours truly,

R. J. Pollock,
Teacher

Ottawa, August 30th, 1926.

Sir,

I have your letter of the 14th instant, informing the Department that Miss Clara Terro has been appointed as teacher of the white and Indian day school at Telegraph Creek for the next school year.

In reply I beg to say that the Department has been informed of her appointment by Mr. Inspector Ditchburn. We have agreed to allow her, as our full share of salary, payment at the rate of $50 per teaching month. She should prepare and forward a report at the end of each quarter on the form for that purpose showing the attendance of the Indian children only. This form she should hand to you, and, if you are satisfied that the same is correct, you should certify and send it to the Department when payment of the salary due at the above rate will be made.

Your obedient servant,

A. F. MacKenzie,
